Lillian's monthly expenses include rent for accommodation and also daily market dues She wants to buy more bananas and aspires to sell only at wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more bananas

loans.name: Agnes Nakato  ‘S Group

texts.en:
Agnes is a leader of 5 members of a group. She is a 30-year-old married woman with 2 children aged 2 and 5 years. One of her children goes to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She rents a two-roomed house where she lives with six people. They have electricity and no piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

She works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She works in Ntinda market selling bed sheets. Agnes works six days a week and uses public transport to and from shopping in Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala. Agnes sells to an average of 10 customers a day. Agnes has been in this business for the five years and has in MCDT for three years, servicing her fifth loan. Her monthly expenses include rent for accommodation, daily market dues, school fees and food. She wants to buy bales of bed sheets and aspires to selling only at wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more bed sheets

loans.name: Sadaina Nakibuye ‘S Group

texts.en:
Sadaina is the leader of 5 members of a group. She is a 39-year-old married woman with 4 children aged between 13 and 19 years. All her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members. She rents a one-roomed house where she lives with six people. They have electricity but no piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

She works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She operates a retail shop in Kampala selling bed sheets. Sadaina works six days a week and uses public transport to and from shopping in Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala. Sadaina sells to an average of 15 customers a day. Agnes has been in this business for ten years and has been in MCDT for five years, servicing her tenth loan. Her monthly expenses include rent for accommodation and also daily market dues, school fees and food. She wants to buy more things for her shop.

loans.use: To buy  merchandise

loans.name: Sitheavy

texts.en:
Mrs. Sitheavy R., 37, and her husband, Mr. Norm Yem, 46, live in a small village in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1995 and have two children, a son and a daughter, who are still small.

Sitheavy has been selling grocery items for two years. She buys them from Chbar Ampov market, located in Phnom Penh, for resale at her home. Her husband is a village chief.

Sitheavy is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Hadjah Nankya‘S Group

texts.en:
Hadjah is a leader of 4 members of a group. She is a 36-year-old married woman with 8 children aged between 9 and 23 years. All her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members. She owns a five-room house where she lives with ten people. They have electricity and piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

She works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She sells matooke (bananas) in Ndeeba Market near Kampala city. Hadjah works seven days a week and doesn’t incur any extra transport costs because she buys from her home. Hadjah sells to an average of 15 customers a day. She is faced with a challenge in the rainy season because she sells from an open place. Hadjah has been in this business for the last three years and has been in MCDT for six years, servicing her twelfth loan and working all this long with the same group mates. Hadjah's monthly expenses include the license fee for her business and school fees. She wants to use this loan to increase the stock of her banana business Hadjah is aspiring to see her business expanding so that she can start buying a whole lorry-full of bananas

loans.use: To buy more bananas

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhorn N., 44, and her husband, Mr. Phat Kim, 35, live in a village along National Road Number Five. Their village is 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married for 20 years and have two daughters who are in school.

Sokhorn has been selling fish for two years. She buys them from Kampong Luong Village, about seven kilometers from her house, and resells them at the Prek Phnao Market. Her husband has been a fisherman for ten years. Besides fishing, he also assists his wife in selling the fish. They supplement their income by growing rice as well.

Sokhorn is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase a water pump machine for growing rice.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump machine.

loans.name: Robinah Nalubega G‘S Group

texts.en:
Robinah is the leader of a 4-member business group. She is 40 years old and married with 7 children. Her children are between the ages of two and 18. Five of her children go to school. The last two children are still too young to attend school. She has a big family, but does not care for any additional family members.

Robinah rents a one-room house where she lives with five people. They have electricity, but no piped water. The family eats three meals a day.

Robinah works in a semi-urban area, which is on the outskirts of Kampala. To earn a living, she sells fish in Namungoona, which is one of the city suburbs. She works seven days a week and uses public transportation to facilitate her business transport needs. She buys fish from Gaba, one of the landing sites near Kampala City. She travels to Gaba twice a week to buy the fish. Robinah sells to an average of 20 customers a day. She has many different types of customers.

Robinah faces many challenges in her business. During the rainy season it is difficult to transport the fish from Gaba, which means she sometimes cannot sell to her customers. Also, she must contend with the fluctuations in fish prices; sometimes she buys them when they are very expensive. She has been in this business for the last five years and has been an MCDT client for four years. This will be her 8th loan. For all fout years, she has been working with the same three other women in her group.

Robinah’s monthly expenses include rent for both her home and business premises, school fees, and feeding her family. She wants to use this loan partly to pay school fees for her children and partly to buy more fish to sell. Robinah aspires to growing her business so one day she can export fish to nearby countries.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell and to pay school fees

loans.name: Yun

texts.en:
Mrs. Yun C., 69, is a widow with three daughters. One of her children is married and lives outside the family home, and one daughter is a hairdresser. Besides her children she also has one son in-law and three grandchildren who are living with her. The family lives in a small village off of the National Road about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh.

Yun has been selling grocery items for two years. She buys them from TaKhmao market for resale in her village. Yun is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Maggie Nabakka ‘S Group

texts.en: Maggie is a leader of 5members of a group.  She is a 30 year married with 4 children aged between 5 and 14 years. All her children go to school.  She takes care of additional family members (two orphans of her late brother). She resides and  rents a two roomed house, which serves as the home for 8 people. The home is equipped with electricity but no  piped water. She works in a semi urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala.   She sells charcoal at her home in Makerere near Kampala city. Maggie works 7 days a week. Maggie has an average of 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people.  Maggie has been in this business for the five years and has an MCDT for one month servicing her first loan. Maggie's monthly expenses include rent for accommodation. She wants to use this loan of $275 to stock more sacks of charcoal .

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Visal

texts.en:
Mr. Visal Chap, and his wife, Mrs. Sokhun Hai, were married in 1988 and have three sons. One of their children is a garment factory worker and the other two children are construction workers. The family lives along the National Road which is about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Visal and his wife have been vegetable wholesalers for 12 years. They bought many types of vegetables from farmers in their village and from near by villages in the Dem Kor market in Phnom Penh. Now, the couple needs one truck to carry their vegetables, but lacks the money.

Therefore, Visal is requesting a loan of $1200 to add in his own money to purchase a truck to carry vegetables for resale.

loans.use: To add in their own money for purchasing a truck to carry vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Agiri Nayiga  ‘S Group

texts.en: Agiri is a 65 year old widow with 4 children ages 30 to 50 years old. She lives in a rented two room house which she shares with five other people. They typically don’t have electricity and piped water at their home. She works in a semi urban area which is located on the outskirts of Kampala.  She sells eatables like chapatti mandazi and pan cakes in the Kamwokya market seven days a week. She rents her business premises and sells on retail. She sells her products to an average of 20 customers per day. Agiri has been in this business for the last sixteen years and has been in MCDT for 13 years and is servicing her twenty seventh loan. Agiri wants to buy a baking flour machine. She hopes to buy a plot of land and own a permanent home.

loans.use: She wants to buy flour mixing machine

loans.name: Irshad Begum M. Sharif Group

texts.en:
Irshad begum baji is 48 years old, married, and has resided in Borewala, Pakistan for the past 30 years. Growing up, she unfortunately could not attain education due to her family’s financial difficulties. She is currently married to M. S., a sweetmeat maker. He has owned his own store for the past 28 years. Irshad baji is the mother of four kids: three sons and one daughter. All of her kids are currently attending the local school, and one of her sons is memorizing the holy book “Quran-e-Pak”.

Irshad baji is a very responsible lady. She helps her husband at the family business, making sweetmeats. She has successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). She is applying again for a loan to buy materials (sugar, cooking oil and dry fruits) to expand her husband’s sweetmeat business.

She joined her current loan group with several women in her local community, all of whom are seeking to expand their family businesses. Sugran baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes selling business. Atharan baji wants a loan to expand her sweetmeat selling business. Maryam baji wants a loan to buy another buffalo for her milk selling business. Ashran baji wants a loan to drive an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for sweetmeat selling business

loans.name: Khuon

texts.en: Khuon S., 34, is married and lives in Kandal, Cambodia. She works in a grocery store while her husband is a mechanic and works as a construction worker.  They have three children and all of them attend school. Due to the her low income and school tuition she doesn't have enough money to expand her grocery inventory. Khuon would like to use this loan to add her grocery products.

loans.use: To add her grocery products.

loans.name: Vong

texts.en: Vong S., 34, lives with his wife in Kandal, Cambodia and works as a motorbike mechanic. He has been working as a mechanic since 2001 and is able to make 5 USD in profit each day. His wife operates a grocery store and sells sugar cane juice from her home. On average, she makes about 5 USD as well. Together they are the parents of 2 children. Vong S. would like to take out a loan to expand his wife's grocery store by increasing her inventory. (S.'s wife is pictured in the photo.)

loans.use: Increasing grocery store inventory

loans.name: Jamila Shaheen Shahid Mahmood Group

texts.en:
Jamila is 37 years old and is married to S. M. who is a cloth merchant for the back 4 years.  They resided in a city named Borewala in Pakistan.  He sells clothing such as shawls, warm clothes and bed sheets. He buys these kinds of items from Multan. Jamila  is a mother of three kids (two sons and one daughter). All of her kids are receiving an education from a local school which is located near to the house. Jamila prepares embroidered dresses to help the financial burden of her husband.  She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to expand her husband’s cloth selling business. 

She is joined in her loan group by a few more women. Asma muzaffar baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her cloth selling business. Rukhsana baji wants a loan to buy (tea and sugar) for her tea stall. Manzooran baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Another Manzooran baji wants a loan to buy jewelry to resell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy clothes to resell

loans.name: I Nengah Dwikayama

texts.id:
Berasal dari keluarga tukang kayu, I Nengah Dwikayama memperoleh warisan ketrampilan yang sangat berharga dari orang tuanya . Sejak masih muda Bapak dari dua orang anak ini kini meneruskan bahkan mengembangkan ketrampilan yang di perolehnya dari turun temurun .Ketrampilan itu adalah membuat Sanggah Yang dalam Umat Hindu bangunan sanggah ini merupakan sejenis Pura Yang terbuat dari Kayu dengan ukuran yang sudah baku yang di letakkan di depan rumah sebagai tempat untuk melakukan Persembahan (sesajen) bagi pemeluk agama Hindu. Dalam pengerjaan sanggah ini memerlukan ketrampilan khusus dan harus dikerjakan oleh orang yang sudah terbiasa seperti halnya dengan I Nengah Dwikayama
Istri dari I Komang Sulasmi ini dalam mengerjakan sebuah sanggah memerlukan waktu kurang lebih satu Minggu, dengan modal bahan (kayu dan alat2 lainya ) berkisar Rp 1.250.000-sd 1.500.000,- tergantung jenis kayu yang di minta oleh pemesan. Sedangkan harga sebuah sanggah saat ini Rp 2.000.000-  . Jadi dalam seminggu pendapatan yang di peroleh I Nengah Dwikayama sebesar Rp 500.000-750.000. Namun begitu I Nengah Dwikayama merasa sangat kawalahan dalam menerima order , hal ini disebabkan oleh karena tidak tersedianya  modal yang cukup untuk membeli bahan baku, khususnya Kayu yang kini semakin sulit di dapat dan harganyapun mahal.
Untuk menunjang usahanya itu I Nengah Dwikayama ingin mendapat tambahan modal dari DINARI yang akan dipergunakan untuk membeli kayu untuk stok , sehingga pada saat ada order I Nengah Dwikayama bisa cepat mengerjakannya.
Dengan tambahan modal ini I Nengah Dwikayama optimis hasil yang di dapat akan lebih baik sehingga mampu menunjang biaya pendidikan kedua Orang anaknya Yang kini telah duduk di bangku SMA.          .
texts.en:
I Nengah Dwikayama is coming from a family of carpenters. From his early age he is already in the business of wood carpentry. He is now a master in making Sanggah, a wooden Pura (Pura is a temple in Hindu faith used to place the offerings).

I Nengah Dwikayama and his wife can build one Sanggah in a week time. They needs woods for the material that usually cost them around USD 130, depending on the type and the quality of the wood. They can sell one Sanggah for around USD 172. So they can earn a net profit of USD 40 per Sanggah sold.

At the moment he is having difficulties in receiving orders from customers. Sometimes he doesn't have enough money to buy the woods to build Sanggahs when he has a lot of orders. Therefore he applies for a loan from DINARI so he can get an additional working capital.

He is hoping with more capital he can meet more orders from the customers. With this he can have more income to support his two children who are studying at High School.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy teak wood

loans.name: Haleema Sheikh Ali Hassan Group

texts.en:
Haleema is 38 years old, married, and lives in Borewala, Pakistan. Her husband, S. A. H., is a driver and operates an auto-rickshaw. Haleema has two daughters, both of whom are attending kindergarten.

Haleema believes in the power of good work. She prepares embroidered dresses and clothes for her neighbors, and is able to earn a steady income from her work. She believes that contributing her own income to the family helps provide her children with the necessary support they need and the education to succeed.

Haleema is currently requesting a loan to help repair and maintain her husband’s auto-rickshaw. She participates in a loan group, which is formed from several women in her local community. Rabia Basri baji wants to purchase groceries and other supplies to restock her own store. Amanat baji wants to expand her current stock of wires and switch boards for her electric item retailing business. Farida baji wants to purchase clothes to expand her own business inventory.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To pay for the installments of auto-rickshaws (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Sofia Nawula  ‘S Group

texts.en: Sofia is the leader of her 5 member loan group. She is a 34 years old and married with 3 young children. All of her children go to school. She resides and rents a two room house which she shares with six people. They have electricity and no piped water at home. The family gets two meals a day and has tea. She works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She works in Makerere at the Kikoni market near Kampala city. Sofia works seven days a week. Sofia sells to an average of 25 customers a day and sells to many people in retail and sells whatever is available for resale. Sofia has been in this business for two years. Sofia's monthly expenses include rent for accommodations and also daily market dues. She wants to buy more vegetables for resale purposes.

loans.use: to buy more Vegetables and fruits

loans.name: Zehar Batool M. Aslam Pervaiz Group

texts.en:
Zehar Batool baji is a 46-year-old married lady and has resided in a city called Borewala, Pakistan for the past 45 years. Her parents couldn’t provide her with an education, and she left school after completing 8th standard. Her husband's name is M. A. P. and he has a rice-selling business. He buys the sacks of rice from different cities (Lahore, Kasur) and sells in different shops in Borewala. He has 20 years of experience in this business.

Zehar baji is the mother of six kids: four daughters and two sons. All of her kids are getting an education from a local school near their house. Zehar baji herself is involved in making decorative pieces. She makes wooden pieces with writing on them: various Holy names, e.g., “Allah and Muhammad”. Her art is very famous in her community and outside of the community as well. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more wooden sticks to expand her decorative pieces business.

She is the group leader for some more women frpm her locality. Parveen Akhtar baji wants a loan to buy bicycles to re-sell. Faizan baji wants a loan to buy wires and switch boards for her electric items business. Majidan baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Shaheen baji wants a loan to buy medicines for her medical store.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy wooden sticks to make decorative pieces to sell

loans.name: Sokhun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhun C., 50, is a widow with one son who has full-time employment in Phnom Penh. The family lives along National Road Number One about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sokhun has been selling meat balls, boiled eggs, and roasted chicken wings for three months. She buys them from Koky market to cook and sells them in her village. Sokhun earns about US$ 2.50 a day from her business. She is just completing repairing her house and lacks some money to pay fees. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of US$ 600 to pay her house’s building fee.

loans.use: To pay her house’s building fee.

loans.name: Shahnaz Javed Iqbal Group

texts.en:
"I am Shahnaz and I’m 45 years old and a married lady. I have been a citizen of a city called Borewala, Pakistan for the past 17 years. I couldn’t get an education because my parents couldn’t afford my education expenses. I got married at the age of 18 to a man whose name is J. I.. He is a clothes merchant with experience of 15 years. He buys clothes from a famous bazaar in the city of Multan and sells them in his native city. My son also works with my husband. I help my husband in his clothes-selling business. I sell his garment collections in the community. I have successfully repaid my two loans from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now I am applying again for a loan to expand my husband’s clothes-selling business.

I’m the group leader for some more women. Another Shahnaz baji and Shaheen baji each want a loan to buy garments to re-sell. Rashida baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit for her fruit-selling business. Shamim Akhtar baji wants a loan to buy wood to re-sell."

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Penh

texts.en:
Mrs. Penh T., 49, and her husband, Mr. Lim Lao, 37, married in 1990 and have four children: one son and three daughters. Two of their children are garment factory workers and the other two children attend school. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Five about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Penh has been growing rice since she was married; besides farming she also sells lotus. She buys them from the villagers in her village for re-sale at the market in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a fisherman and does farming. Penh is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to build a staircase in her house.

loans.use: To build a staircase in her house

loans.name: Majida Safdar Masih Group

texts.en:
Majida baji is a 32-year-old married lady and a citizen of a city named Borewala, Pakistan. Her parents were not able to provide her education, so she dropped out from the school after 5th standard. Her husband's name is S. M., who is a mason by profession. She is the mother of five sons. Her eldest son works in a workshop. The others are enrolled in a local school which is located near to the house. Majida baji has a Punjabi food selling business. She does this work to help her husband so that he is able to meet the financial expenses. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy mason tools for her husband. 

She is a group leader of some more women of her locality. Kosar baji wants a loan to buy fertilizer to resell. Rafiqan baji wants a loan for mason tools. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy a welding machine. Hanifan baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Rafiqan baji wants a loan to buy mason tools. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy mason tools

loans.name: Chinnerau

texts.en:
Mr. Chinnerau U., 33, and his wife, Mrs. Theary Moeurn, 30, have been married for ten years. They have two children: one son and one daughter, both of whom are still young. The family lives in a small village across Mekong River about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Chinnerau has been a security guard in Phnom Penh for three years. His wife has been selling silk fabric for four years. She buys them from a market in Phnom Penh for resale at the other provinces. Chinnerau is requesting his first loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike and a passenger trailer to drive a motor taxi (Tuk Tuk).

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and a passenger trailer to drive a motor taxi (Tuk Tuk).

loans.name: Kalsoom M. Iqbal Group

texts.en:
My name is Kalsoom and I am 46 years old. I have resided in a city named Borewala, Pakistan, for the past 37 years. My parents were not able to give me good education because of their little financial resources. I am married to a man whose name is M. I. and he has been a vegetable seller for the past 10 years. I am a mother of six kids: two sons and four daughters. My elder son works in a factory. Another reads in 4th standard. My elder daughter is married and she and her husband also live with us. My son-in-law has a spare parts selling business. My other daughters are getting education from a school which located near to the house.

I believe in hard work and I transfer this value to my kids also. I get up early and do household work, and then I help my husband in setting the vegetables on his cart. I have successfully repaid my first loan which I took from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am applying again for a loan to buy spare parts to expand my son-in-law’s spare parts selling business.

I’m a group leader of some more women of my locality. Farzana firdous baji and Majidan baji each want a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Razia baji wants a loan to buy iron to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy spare parts to sell

loans.name: Vannak

texts.en:
Mr. Vannak M., 46, and his wife, Mrs. Rady Sok, 45, live in a small village along National Road Number Two about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1984 and have seven children: three sons and four daughters. One of their children is married but lives inside the family home, four children attend school, one child has full time employment and the other one is still young.

Vannak has been a mason since 1984, a skill he learned from his father. His wife has been a tailor for one year; she sews at her own house. Vannak is asking for a loan of $300 purchase a motorbike for his child to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for his son to drive to work.

loans.name: Amer

texts.en:
Amer is a 31-year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Amer has been working as a mason for eight years. He requested a loan of 500 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools and wood for his business. This is the first time that Amer has requested a loan.

Amer is special in his work because he does it well and he is honest with his clients. His clients can be anybody from his area and the surrounding villages. When he first started his business, he didn’t have the startup capital needed. In the future, Amer plans to expand his business by increasing his clients.

loans.use: Amer will use the loan to purchase tools and wood for his business.

loans.name: Bunnarith

texts.en:
Mr. Bunnarith H., 39, and his wife, Mrs. Sokmoeun Soy, 32, live in a small village off National Road Number Two, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1994 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. One of their children attends school and another one is still young.

Bunnarith has been driving a motor cart for two years. He carries garment factory workers from his village to the garment factory, and from garment factory back to his village. His wife has been a garment factory worker since 1991. Bunnarith is requesting a loan of US$300 to pay for his house remodeling fee.

loans.use: To pay for his house remodeling fee.

loans.name: Parveen Patras Group

texts.en:
My name is Parveen and I've been a citizen of a city named Borewala, Pakistan, for the past 25 years. I couldn’t continue my education after 8th standard due to the little financial resources of my parents. I am married to a man whose name is P. and he is a driver by profession, driving an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). He has been driving this for the past 16 years.

I am a mother of three kids: two sons and one daughter. All of my kids are getting education from a local school. I stay at home and sew clothes of my neighbors. I sew clothes to help my husband to meet the financial expenses of the household. I have successfully repaid my two previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am applying again for a loan to change the body of my husband's auto-rickshaw so that he is able to continue his work.

I’m a group leader of some more women of my locality. Rozina baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Khairan baji wants a loan to buy sanitary supplies to sell. Shamshad baji wants a loan to buy goats for her animal selling business. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To change the body of the auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Houssein

texts.en:
Houssein is a 21-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon. He has been selling cassettes and DVDs for a year and a half. Houssein is requesting a loan of $1000 dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise and do some maintenance work in his shop. This is the first time that Houssein has requested a loan.

Houssein shop is special because he is always aware of the new releases and always makes sure that he has them on time. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had difficulties purchasing a store. He started his business because he likes being independent. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise and do some maintenance work in the shop

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mrs. Pov K., 45, and her husband, Mr. An Nao, 61, who live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1983 and have seven children. Five of their children are married and live outside the family home; one of her daughters attends school and another one stays at home.

Pov has been a silk weaver since she was 14 years old, a skill she learned from a relative. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a farmer. He grows jicamas and corn in the farm a distance from his house. Pov is requesting a loan of US$ 300 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Teng

texts.en: Teng C. is 29 years old and lives in Sa Ang district, Phnom Penh. She grows rice and weaves scarves to earn a living and is able to make about US$ 3 per day. Her husband also grows rice and raises pigs. He makes around US$ 2 each day. This couple has two school-aged children. Mrs. Teng C. is asking for a loan to purchase silk and fertilizer.

loans.use: To purchase silk and fertilizer

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a 37-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Hassan has been working as a school bus driver for a year. He likes being independent.

He requests a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his bus and pay his debts. This is the first time that Hassan has requested a loan. In the future, he plans to purchase a bigger bus.

loans.use: Do some maintenance work on the school bus and pay debts

loans.name: Vutha

texts.en: Vutha N., 22, lives in Sa Ang district, Phnom Penh. She grows vegetables and weaves scarves to earn approximately US$ 3 every day. Her husband grows rice and vegetables and makes about US$ 2 a day. This couple has three children, two of whom are students and one weaves at home. Mrs. Vutha is asking for a loan of US$ 700 to purchase more silk to weave more scarves and buy fertilizer to put on her farmland.

loans.use: To purchase silk and fertilizer

loans.name: Yan

texts.en:
Mr. Yan Y., 61, and his wife, Mrs. Mot Prum, 53, who live in a small village in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, married in 1979 and have three children: two sons who are married and live outside the family home, and one daughter.

Yan and his wife have been growing rice since they married. Yan hopes to continue his business. He is requesting a loan of US$ 400 to use for growing rice.

loans.use: To use for growing rice

loans.name: Vong

texts.en: Vong S., 24, is married and lives with her husband in Sa Ang district, Phnom Penh. Since 2004, she and her husband have been working growing rice and raising pigs to earn a living and are able to make around US$ 3 each day. This couple has one young child. To make more money, Vong would like to use this loan to breed more pigs and purchase feed for them as well.

loans.use: Raise more pigs and buy feed for them

loans.name: Abbass

texts.en:
Abbass is a 28-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, southern Lebanon. Abbass has owned an electrical shop for 15 years. He sells tools and supplies for the extension of electricity. Abbass is requesting a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a car for his work. This is the first time that Abbass has requested a loan.

His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Abbass first started his business, he had difficulty building a network of clients. He decided to start his business because he wanted to improve his financial condition. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: Purchase a car for the business

loans.name: Sophoin

texts.en:
Mr. Sophoin N., 30, and his wife, Mrs. Sreytouch Phan, 30, who live in a small village in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, have been married for ten years and have three children: two sons and one daughter, all of whom attend school.

Sophoin has been growing vegetables for eight years. He also buys them from the villagers in his village for re-sale at the market in Phnom Penh. His wife has been raising ducks for ten years, a skill she learned by herself. Sophoin and his wife hope to set up their own shop to sell food and rice. Sophoin is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase a trailer to carry vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to carry vegetables to sell

loans.name: Abbass

texts.en:
Abass is a 31-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, southern Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Abass has been working as a car mechanic. He has been repairing and selling diesel cars for 8 years. He is requesting a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is his second request for a loan. He always made his loan payments on time. His previous loan helped him improve his business.

Abass is a special businessman because his is trustworthy. His clients are his friends and neighbors. He started his business because he wanted to earn more cash and be independent. When he first started his business, he had difficulty finding clients. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: Purchase tools for diesel car repair business

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 60-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, southern Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Ali has been working as a farmer for 4 years. He sells vegetables. He is requesting a loan of $1100 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase seedlings.

Ali has been a microcredit client for 7 years now and has always paid on time. His previous loans have influenced his work as well as his life in a good way. Thanks to his loans, he was able to improve and expand his business and his family situation at the same time. His clients are his friends and neighbors. In the future, he plans to expand his business by growing more vegetables.

loans.use: Purchase vegetable seedlings to plan

loans.name: Som

texts.en: Som S. is 36 years old and lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She is a garment factory worker and earns US$ 2.50 per day. Her husband Leng Horn, 39, pictured here, works growing vegetables and selling them at the market near his house. On average, he makes US$ 3 a day. This couple has four children; three are in school and one is a garment worker. This couple would like to purchase a water pump, fertilizer, and seeds to expand their cultivation.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump, fertilizer, and seeds

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Navin

texts.en:
Mrs. Navin Chheang, 23, who lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 2007 and has one daughter.

Navin has been a silk weaver since she was 14 years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a silk weaver and a construction worker as well.

Navin is requesting her first loan of US$ 200 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a 35-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, southern Lebanon, with his wife. He has been working as a carpenter, selling and manufacturing furniture for 12 years. Ibrahim has a reputation for doing good work. His clients are his friends and neighbors. Ibrahim requests a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase supplies for his work and also save some money.

This is Ibrahim's third loan and he has always paid on time. His previous loans have helped him improve his business as well as his financial situation. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: Ibrahim will use the loan to purchase supplies for furniture-making business

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Madame  Aminata Doucouré  est âgée de 50 ans, mariée elle vit avec son mari et ses 6 enfants  dans une grande  famille traditionnelle avec d’autres ménagers dans le quartier Secoura de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fait  l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle faisait le petit commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des céréales. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage elle a maîtrisé les rouages du commerce et a acquis assez d’expériences pour évoluer seule. Elle décida de faire le commerce d’atiéké depuis 20 ans et jouit d’une grande réputation au marché château  et dans toute la ville de Ségou où ses clients n’en finissent pas. Son Atieké est  soigneusement tamisé avant d’être mis soit dans des sacs ou emballages en plastiques.
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle en nette croissance, elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro  Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis plusieurs années. Après 5 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels, tous remboursés sans difficulté, elle est son 3ème prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 3 tonnes d’atiéké en république de la  Côte d’Ivoire. Madame  Aminata Doucouré  vend au comptant et à crédit à une cliente composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Avec ce prêt elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000FCFA, ce qui lui servira à se prendre en charge et de payer les frais scolaires de ses enfants. Son ambition est de construire une maison.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aminata Doucouré, 50, is married and lives with her husband and 6 children in a big traditional family with other housewives in the Secoura neighborhood of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Having been unable to attend school for socio-economic reasons, she began working as a petty trader together with her mother who sold cereals. After a number of years of apprenticeship, she became well-versed in the ways of commerce and had enough experience to continue on her own. She decided to sell atiéké 20 years ago and enjoys an excellent reputation in the "château" market and in all the town of Ségou where she has innumerable customers. Her "Atieké" (granulated cassava) is carefully sieved before being filled into sacks or plastic wrappers.

So as to satisfy her clientele and grow her business, she came to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. She has been working with us for several years. After 5 group loans and 2 individual loans, all reimbursed without difficulty, she is on her third individual loan.

She intends to use this loan to buy 3 tons of atiéké in the Republic of Côte d’Ivoire. Mrs. Aminata Doucouré sells for cash and credit to a clientele composed of men and women. With this loan she expects to make a monthly profit of 150,000 F CFA which she will use to support herself and pay her children's school fees. Her ambition is to build a house.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing Atiéké (cassava granules) for re-sale

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi ont en moyenne  37 ans et 4 enfants. Toutes mariées, ils vivent  en majorité dans des familles polygamiques au quartier Bamanan Kin Kirango de Markala Préfecture de Ségou(quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles se sont connues depuis à bas âge, ont grandi ensemble, sont restées unies même après leurs mariages dans le même quartier. Elles sont toutes membres de l’association  traditionnelle dénommée Faïda. Elles ont connu Soro Yiriwaso à travers l’assemblée générale des artisans de la commune de Markala au cours de laquelle toutes les associations féminines ont été conviées. 
Après avoir bien remboursé les prêts précédents, le groupe est à son 4ème prêt qui  sera utilisé pour acheter, 1 sac de concombre, 2 cartons de banane plantain, 1 sac d’orange, ½ sac de citron, 1sac de racines du doum > et 6 cartons de savon. Ces produits sont achetés une fois par semaine à la foire de Diamarabougou. A côté de ceux-ci elles font le petit commerce de haricot, de condiments alimentaires, des jarres et des canaris confectionnés à Kounkobougou et livrés à domicile spécialement aux revendeuses à Kirango. Ces produits sont vendus au comptant et à crédit  à  une clientèle composée  de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 22 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt,  payer les tontines et l’habillement des enfants. Elles ont pour ambition  d’avoir une maison d’habitation
texts.en:
The women of the Benkadi group have an average age of 37 years and on average, 4 children. All are married and most live in polygamous families in the Bamanan Kin Kirango neighborhood of Markala, prefecture of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They have known each other since they were children, grew up together, and remained close even after their marriages, in the same neighborhood. They are all members of a traditional association called Faïda. They learned about Soro Yiriwaso from the general assembly of artisans of the Markala community, during which all the women's associations convene.

After having reimbursed their preceding loans, the group is on their 4th loan which will be used to buy 1 sack of cucumbers, 2 cases of plantains, 1 sack of oranges, 1/2 sack of lemons, 1 sack of roots of doum palms, and 6 cases of soap. These products are bought once a week at the market fair of Diamarabougou. Besides these items, they sell beans, condiments, and jars and storage pots made in Kounkobougou and specially delivered to the homes of saleswomen in Kirango.

These products are sold for cash and on credit to a clientele composed of women and men. They expect to make an average profit of 22,000 F CFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan, save money in traditional associations, and dress their children. Their ambition is to have a house to live in.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy various items for re-sale

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya ont en moyenne 47 ans et vivent majoritairement dans des familles polygamiques avec en moyenne 5 enfants à Markala (quatrième région administrative du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers  des liens de voisinage et de mariage dans le quartier Bamanan Kin de Kirango et se trouvent  dans l’association traditionnelle  de tontine des femmes il y’a une dizaine d’année. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de différents articles qui va des céréales aux condiments alimentaires sans oublier les activités génératrices de revenus opportunistes (articles achetés et vendus occasionnellement suite à tel ou tel événement).
Elles sont  à leur 4ème cycle après 3 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) correctement remboursés.
Ce prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter,  19 sacs de mils, 14 sacs de haricots, 2 sacs d’arachides, 1 sac de piments, 2 sacs de sel iodé et 25 kgs de poudres de baobab et de gombo.
Elles s’approvisionnent en céréales à Dougabougou et Séribala et en condiments alimentaires à la foire de Markala une fois par semaine. Tous ces produits sont vendus au marché de Kirango et de Diamarambougou   au comptant et à crédit  à  une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes. 
Leur bénéfice moyen  escompté est estimé à 41 250 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser  les prêts de Soro Yiriwaso et payer les tontines.
texts.en:
The members of the Danaya group have an average age of 47 and live mostly in polygamous families with an average of 5 children in Markala (fourth administrative region of Mali). They met because of proximity or because of being in-laws in the Bamanan Kin neighborhood of Kirango and have been meeting in a traditional savings association for women for about 10 years.

This group of women sells various articles, from cereals to condiments, but they also take advantage of occasional opportunities to make some money (buying and selling articles as the occasion permits). They are on their 4th group loan after having correctly reimbursed 3 group (solidarity) loans. The loan will be used to buy 19 sacks of millet, 14 sacks of beans, 2 sacks of peanuts, 1 sack of hot peppers, 2 sacks of iodized salt, and 25 kgs of powdered baobab fruit and powdered okra.

They buy their cereals in Dougabougou and Séribala and their condiments at the market fair in Markala once a week. All these products are sold in the markets in Kirango and Diamarambougou for cash or on credit to a clientele essentially made up of women. Their discounted average profit is estimated at 41,250 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the Soro Yiriwaso loans and make deposits to their traditional savings association.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cereals and condiments

loans.name: Set

texts.en:
Mr. Set L., 52, and his wife, Mrs. Nub Sai, 49, married in 1980 and have six children: three sons and three daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the famiL. home, one daughter is a silk weaver, and another one is a fisherman. The famiL. lives along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Set has been a fisherman for 30 years, a skill he learned when he was young. He catches fish from the Mekong River and a lake near his village. Mrs. Nub Sai sells the fish that her husband catches at a local market. Set is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to purchase a motor for his fishing boat.

loans.use: To purchase a motor for his fishing boat

loans.name: Dèmè Group

texts.fr:
Les huit (08) femmes du groupe Dèmè ont un âge moyen de 39 ans toutes mariées, elles vivent à moitié dans des familles polygamiques avec les beaux parents et d’autres ménages au quartier Bozo Diamarabougou de Markala (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles ont en moyenne 4 enfants et se sont connues par les liens d’amitié et de voisinage.
Ce groupe fait le commerce des articles divers.
Après avoir bien remboursé les prêts précédents, le groupe est à son 4ème prêt pour un montant de 1 000 000FCFA qui  sera utilisé pour acheter, 90 paniers de poissons frais, 6 sacs de riz, 1 sac de fonio, 50kgs de graines d’arachide et divers autres articles. Elles s’approvisionnent en poisson au bord du fleuve Niger ; le riz et le fonio sont achetés à la foire hebdomadaire de Diamarabougou et à Dougabougou. Le poisson est vendu à Markala et à Ségou a l’état frais frit et /ou fumé. Le riz est revendu tel qu’il est alors que le fonio est transformé en  sur place au Bozo kin Diamarabougou. A côté de ces produits, elles vendent un peu de bois  de chauffe et de condiments achetés respectivement à Fakelen et Diamarabougou où ils sont revendus. Ces produits sont vendus au comptant ou à crédit  à  une clientèle composée  de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 37 660 FCFA  qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour rembourser les prêts de Soro Yiriwaso et payer les frais scolaires des enfants. Elles ont pour ambition d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce et le volume de     leurs activités commerciales afin d’avoir un jour une maison d’habitation qui leur est propre.
texts.en:
The 8 women of the Dèmè group have an average age of 39. They are all married and half of them live in polygamous families with their parents-in-law and the others in households in the Bozo Diamarabougou district of Markala (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They have on average 4 children each and know each other because of friendships and from living in the same neighborhood. This group sells various items.

After having correctly reimbursed their preceding loans, the group is on their 4th loan in the amount of 1,000,000 F CFA which will be used to buy 90 baskets of fresh fish, 6 sacks of rice, 1 sack of "fonio" (a type of millet), 50 kgs of peaunts and various other items. They buy their fish on the banks of the Niger river; the rice and fonio are bought at the weekly markets of Diamarabougou and Dougabougou. The fish is sold in Markala and Ségou, either fried or smoked. The rice is sold as is, whereas the fonio is processed right in Bozo Kin Diamarabougou. Besides these products, they sell a little firewood as well as condiments bought in Fakelen and Diamarabougou where they are re-sold. These products are sold for cash or credit to a clientele composed of women and men.

They expect to make an average profit of 37,660 F CFA which will be used essentially to reimburse the Soro Yiriwaso loan and pay the school fees for their children. Their ambition is to grow their working capital and the volume of their businesses so as to be able to have their own homes one day.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella A. is 43 years old and married with 5 children. She sells chickens in the market, and she plans to increase her sales. She is requesting the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more chickens for sale.  She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens to sell

loans.name: Vong

texts.en:
Mr. Vong A., 45, and his wife, Mrs. Phalla Mean, 43, have been married for 22 years and have four children: one son who is a construction worker and three daughters. Two of their daughters are garment factory workers and another one is in school. The family lives in a small village off of National Road Number Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Vong has been a mason for 25 years. He does his work in Phnom Penh and near his village. His wife stays at home and takes care of their family. The couple is in the process of building their new house and they lack money to build a staircase. Therefore, Vong is requesting his first loan of US$ 300 to build a staircase on his house.

loans.use: To build a staircase on his house

loans.name: Kankélentigui (Qui Teint Parole) Group

texts.fr:
Les huit (08) membres du groupe Kankélentigui ont en moyenne 49ans et vivent majoritairement dans des familles monogamiques avec en moyenne 5 enfants à Markala (quatrième région administrative du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers  des liens de voisinage dans le quartier Rail Ko de Diamarabougou. Elles font essentiellement l’achat et la vente des céréales, du bois de chauffe et des condiments. D’autres font de temps à autre de la restauration.
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin leurs clientèles les femmes du groupe Kankélentigui ont décidé d’adhérer le programme crédit de l’institution avec laquelle elles sont à leur 4ème prêt, après avoir bien remboursé les trois prêts précédents.
Elles comptent utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, 4 cartons de  concentrée de tomate, 4 sacs de sel iodé, 25kg de Soumbala, 2 cartons de cubes maggi, 2 sacs de choux pommés, 2 sacs de pomme de terre, 34 poulets et 37 kg de poisson frais. Parfois elles vendent aussi du bois de chauffe à domicile. Elles se ravitaillent en condiments à Markala une fois par semaine à la foire, en poulet à Dougabougou et parfois sur place à Markala ; en poisson frais au bord du fleuve Niger. Les produits sont vendus au marché de Diamarabougou et dans des gargotes aménagées à domicile,  au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 37 000FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et la prise en charge des fournitures scolaires des enfants.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Kankélentigui group have an average age of 49 and mostly live in monogamous families with on average 5 children in Markala (fourth administrative region of Mali). They know each other because they are related to each other and live in the community of Rail Ko of Diamarabougou. They essentially buy and sell cereals, firewood, and condiments. Others sell cooked food from time to time.

With the intention of satisfying their clientele, the women of the Kankélentigui group decided to join the loan program of the institution with whom they are on their 4th loan, after having reimbursed the three preceding ones.

They intend to use this new loan to buy 4 cases of tomato paste, 4 sacks of iodized salt, 25 kg of "Soumbala" (a condiment), 2 cases of Maggi cubes, 2 sacks of cabbages, 2 sacks of potatoes, 34 chickens, and 37 kg of fresh fish. Sometimes they also sell firewood out of their homes. They buy their condiments in Markala once a week at the fair, their chickens come from Dougabougou or are bought right in Markala; their fresh fish is bought on the banks of the Niger River. The products are sold at the market of Diamarabougou and out of sheds set up at their homes, for cash and on credit to a clientele composed of women and men. They hope to make an average profit of 37,000 F CFA per month which will be used to make repayments on the loan and to pay their children's school fees.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments and other articles, among them items for food service

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles K. is 34 years old, married with three children. He is a generous man, supporting some orphans in an orphanage. He  began selling cosmetics in 2003. He is using the loan to expand his business by purchasing more cosmetics. With the income from the business, he intends to build a residential house on his plot of land. He also aspires to educate his children to the university level.

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics for re-sale

loans.name: Jamil

texts.en:
Jamil L. is a hard-working man, aged 46. He is married with 5 children. L. runs a metal workshop in Zana which he set up in 2001. With a need to expand his business, he is using the loan proceeds in purchasing steel bars and metal sheets.

L. is skilled at making gates, doors, windows, fence poles and metallic furniture. The income from the business enables him to sustain his family. He has a plan to set up a poultry farm in his village so as to supplement the income he earns from the metal workshop. He hopes that the income from the two businesses will enable him to educate his children.

loans.use: Purchasing steel bars and metal sheets

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokha S., 48, and her husband, Mr. Roeun Khiev, 49, have been married for 20 years and have six children: two sons and four daughters. One of their children is married and lives outside the family home; two daughters are garment factory workers; one son is a driver, and two children attend school. The family lives in a small village off of National Road Number Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sokha is a housewife. She looks after her house and takes care of the children. Roeun has been a driver for a construction company for fourteen years. Currently, their daughters go to work by motor taxi and the cost is high and they decided to buy a motorbike for their daughters to ride to work but they lack money to do so.

Therefore, Sokha is requesting her first loan of US$ 500 to buy a motorbike for her daughters to ride to work.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her daughters to ride to work.

loans.name: Kolaban Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq (05) membres du groupe kolaban vivent majoritairement dans des familles polygamiques  avec en moyenne 43 ans et 3 enfants. Elles se sont connues à travers  des liens de voisinage dans le quartier rail ko de Diamarabougou et militaient toutes dans l’association traditionnelle. Elles font essentiellement les activités  d’achat et de vente des céréales, de poisson de savon et charbon de bois
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de plus en plus grandissant de leur clientèle, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de  Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel elles sont à leur 2ème prêt; après avoir bien remboursé le premier prêt.
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 405 kg de poisson frais dont une partie est vendue frais et l’autre moitié frite et des sacs de charbon de bois. Elles se ravitaillent en poisson frais tous les jours au bord du fleuve Niger et au marché de Kirango. Tandis que le charbon de bois est vendu à domicile, le poisson est vendu frais en ambulant dans le quartier rail ko et frit en face de l’hôpital au comptant et parfois à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 41 250FCFA par mois utilisé généralement pour, rembourser les intérêts du prêt, la prise en charge des frais scolaires des enfants,  subvenir aux besoins familiaux et le  payement de la tontine. Elles ont pour ambition  d’avoir une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The five members of the group Kolaban live for the most part in polygamous families and average 43 years of age and three children. They know one another through community ties in the Rail Ko district of Diamarabougou. They are all highly active in the traditional association and work essentially in buying and selling grain, fish, soap, and charcoal.

Concerned about satisfying their burgeoning customer base, they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program, with which they are on their second loan, the first one being repaid. The new loan will be use to buy: 405 kg of fresh fish (some of it sold fresh and half of it fried), sacks of onion, and charcoal. Supplies of fish are gotten every day on the banks of the Niger River and at the Kirango marketplace. While the charcoal is sold at home, the fish is sold fresh door-to-door in the Rail Ko district and is also sold fried across from the hospital. Cash is accepted, and sometimes credit, from customers composed of women and men.

The group members intend to realize an average profit of 41,250 francs CFA per month that will be used generally for paying the loan interest, covering the school costs for the children, providing for family needs, and making payments to the tontine (community revolving credit system). Their ambition is to have a house.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish and charcoal

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Y. Sarah is 43 years old. She is married with 4 children, of whom one has completed studies. Since 1998, Sarah has been selling tailoring materials in Kampala city. She is using the loan to purchase more yards of fabric, threads, needles, tracing papers, among other items. She hopes that once her business becomes financially sustainable, she will be in position to save money and complete her commercial building which is halfway under construction.

loans.use: Purchasing more yards of fabric, threads, needles, tracing papers, among others.

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna M., 56, and her husband, Mr. Yun Morm, 66, live in a small village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1979 and have one son who is married. Besides her son she also has one daughter in-law and three grandchildren living with her. 

Vanna and her husband have been farming for 20 years. They grow tomatoes, eggplants, and corn in their farmland near the house. Their son takes the produce and buys some amount from their villagers to sell at market in Phnom Penh.

Vanna is requesting a loan of $1100 to purchase a motorbike and trailer for her son driving as a motor taxi (Tuk Tuk) and carry vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and trailer for her son driving motor taxi (Tuk Tuk).

loans.name: Haisy

texts.en:
Haisy N. is a business lady aged 42. She has 3 children, all of them in school. Mrs. N. ventured into the retail business in 2005. She mainly sells hairdressing materials in her shop. The income from her business enables her to educate her children.

To expand her business, Mrs. N. is planning on purchasing more hair extensions and oils. Besides, she earns some side income from rearing poultry and livestock. She hopes to buy land and build some commercial houses.

loans.use: Purchase hair additions and oils

loans.name: Teymas

texts.en:
Mrs. Teymas S., 50, and her husband, Mr. Ly Sen, 58, married during the Pol Pot regime and have five children: four sons and one daughter. Three of their children are married and live outside the family home, and the other two children are in school. The family lives along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Teymas built a water storage tower and has connected it to houses in the neighborhood. She runs a private water utility service. Her husband has been building boats to sell for 15 years, a skill he learned from his father. Teymas is requesting a loan of US$ 800 to purchase wood materials for her husband to use to build boats to sell.

loans.use: To purchase wood materials for her husband to build boats to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine Nyungula is a business lady aged  39. She has a retail shop in Nateete which she set up in 2002. She has 2 school-going children. She is a hard-working lady  with a vision of expanding her retail business into a supermarket. She is using the loan proceeds to purchase rice, sugar, flour, and soap for her business. She intends to purchase a piece of land with the income she earns from the business.

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar, flour and soap

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en: Svetlana is 27 years old, married, has two children. She sells women's clothing at Khoost market. Svetlana has been in this business for 9 years already. She likes selling women's clothing and likes working with customers. Svetlana's customers like buying from her as well. Besides that, her good location at the central market provides stable income. Svetlana is asking for a loan of 8,000 UAH to increase the assortment of her goods. She hopes to increase her sales and spend the extra profit to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to increase the assortment of her goods

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeun N., 48, and her husband, Mr. Vorn Torn, 48, who live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1980 and have eight children: six sons and two daughters. One of their sons is married and lives outside the family home; two children are silk weavers, and two other children attend school while another child is still young.

Soeun has been a silk weaver since she was 20 years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been farming and raising cows since he was young. Soeun is requesting her first loan of US$ 200 for her husband to use to begin growing ginger.

loans.use: For growing ginger

loans.name: Mhammad

texts.en:
Mhammad is a 48-year-old man who lives in Bourj el Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon, with his wife and their child. Mhammad repairs cars. He requests a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his garage. Mhammad is very good at repairing cars and he has a good relationship with his clients. His clients are his friends and neighbors. He started his business because he wants to be independent and he likes cars.

Mhammad has been a microcredit client for 5 years and has always paid on time. His previous loans have influenced his life in a good way; thanks to the loans, he was able to improve his work and his family situation. In the future, he plans to expand and improve his business.

loans.use: Purchase tools for car repair garage

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en:
Lawrence S. is a hard-working man aged 32, married with 2 young children. Lawrence runs a bar in Makindye and also purchases matooke and chilli from the villages and exports them to London. Due to the quality of the products he sells, his business has been in existence since 2005.

He is using the loan proceeds to boost both businesses by purchasing more crates of beer, wines, and spirits and also more matooke (green bananas) and chilli for export. He intends to reinvest the profits back into the business. His desire is to educate his children through university.

loans.use: Purchasing more crates of beer, etc.and more matooke (green bananas) and chilli for export

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Les six (06) membres du groupe Sabougnouman ont en moyenne 39 ans et vivent majoritairement dans des familles polygamiques avec en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles se sont connues à travers  des liens de voisinage dans le quartier Raïl Ko de Diamarabougou et militent toutes dans l’association traditionnelle  de tontine des femmes du quartier (Badenya) depuis octobre 1986.
Elles ont connu Soro Yiriwaso à travers une assemblée générale des artisans de Markala à laquelle toutes les associations féminines de la commune étaient conviées ; c’est ainsi que ces femmes ont adhéré le programme du crédit solidaire où elles sont à leur 3ème prêt, après avoir bien remboursé les deux premiers prêts. 
Ce prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter 6 paniers de poissons frais ,3 paniers  de tomates fraîches, 2 sacs d’oignons frais, 1 sac des choux pommés, 1 sac d’aubergine, 3 pièces de bazins de 10 pièces de pagnes Wax et 6 sacs de riz. 
Elles s’approvisionnent en poisson au bord du fleuve Niger dans les zones de pêche de  Markala. Les condiments sont achetés hebdomadairement  à la foire de Markala. Les  habits sont achetés une fois par mois à Bamako et le riz à Kolongo une fois par mois aussi. Tous ces produits sont vendus à Markala au marché et à domicile au comptant et à crédit. Leur clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes. Leur bénéfice moyen  est de 30 670 FCFA, qui sera utilisé pour compléter les frais de condiments et le paiement de la tontine. Elles ont comme ambition d’augmenter le volume et de  diversifier leurs activités.
texts.en:
The six members of the group Sabougnouman average 39 years of age and live for the most part in polygamous families with three children on average. They know one another through community ties in the Rail Ko district of Diamarabougou and have all been highly active in the tontine (a traditional revolving credit association) of the women of the Badenya district since October 1986.

The women are familiar with Soro Yiriwaso through a gathering of Markala artisans to which all the women's associations in the community had been invited. That is why these women have joined the loan program, with which they are on their third solidarity loan (group loan), since the first two have been repaid.

This new loan will be used to buy: 6 baskets of fresh fish, 3 baskets of fresh tomatoes, 2 sacks of fresh onions, 1 sack of cabbages, 1 sack of eggplants, 2 lengths of damask fabrics, 10 lengths of WAX brand pagnes (a colorful West African cloth), and 6 sacks of rice. Supplies of fish are gotten on the banks of the Niger River from the fisheries of Markala. Condiments are purchased weekly at the Markala fair. Clothing is purchased once a month in Bamako, and the rice, in Kolongo, once a month as well. All these goods are sold in Markala at the marketplace and at home, cash or credit accepted. Their customers are composed of men and women.

Their average profit is 30,670 francs CFA, which will be used for making up the cost of the condiments and for paying the tontine. The ambition of the group members is to increase their volume and to diversify their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a 56-year-old woman who lives in Bourj el Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon, with her husband and their seven children. Fatima has owned a grocery store for 6 years. She is able to supplement her family’s income with the profit from her grocery store. Fatima has a good reputation in her area and she has competitive prices. Her clients are

her friends and neighbors. She requests a loan of $1000 from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise to sell in her store. Fatima has been a microcredit client for 8 years and has always paid on time. Her previous loans have influenced her life in a good way; thanks to the loans, she was able to improve her work and her family situation. In the future, she plans to expand and improve her business.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise to sell in the grocery store

loans.name: James

texts.en: James K., 47, operates a restaurant in a mass market. He is a determined businessman, married with 2 children of whom one is in school. He has 28 years experience in the business. Besides, K.’s other sources of income are a bar and a clothing business. He is using the loan funds in purchasing more foodstuffs like rice, sugar, flour, and beans for his restaurant. His dream is to open up a chain of restaurants.

loans.use: Purchasing more foodstuffs like rice, sugar, flour, and beans

loans.name: San

texts.en:
Mrs. San M., 32, and her husband married in 2004 and have one young daughter. She lives with her parents and two nephews and one niece in a small village across the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

San has been a silk weaver for 5 years. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell at the market in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a driver. He drives a truck to transport goods and fruit for a private company.

This is San’s third loan. This time, she is requesting a loan of US$ 400 to purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: John

texts.en: John N.  is 31 years old. He started up his retail shop in 2006. Due insufficient inventory, John is using the loan proceeds in purchasing sugar, salt, flour, and cereals. His business is located in a busy market area thereby attracting a good number of customers. He plans to use the income from the business to purchase a piece of land on which he will set up his residence.

loans.use: Purchasing sugar, salt, flour, and cereals

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 28-year-old man who lives in Bekaa, Lebanon. Mohamad has owned a computer store for 10 years. He has been selling computer software. He also does computer maintenance and repairs. He is an experienced businessman, who worked with computers before he started his own business. His clients are his friends and neighbors from his area.

Mohamad requests a loan of $1200 from A. Majmoua in order to purchase computer spare parts and new computers. This is the first time that Mohamad has requested a loan. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: Purchase computer spare parts and new computers

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en:
Hasan is a 25-year-old man who lives in Bekaa, Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Hasan has been working in livestock production for 5 years. Hasan started his business because he likes animals. He sells the animals in the market.

Hasan requests a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase the land he has been working on. This is the first time that Hasan has requested a loan. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: Purchase the land he has been working on raising livestock

loans.name: Noeun

texts.en:
Mr. Noeun N., 36, and his wife, Mrs. Huon Ul, 34, have been married for 15 years and have three children: one son and two daughters. Two of their children are in school and the other one is still young. The family lives in a small village off of National Road Number Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh.

Noeun and his wife have been selling fish and vegetables for five years. They buy them from Prek Toch market about fifteen kilometers from their home for re-sale at the market in Phnom Penh. Noerun is the process of building his new house but he lacks money to finish part of it. So, he is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to add to his own money to finish his house.

loans.use: To add to his own money to finish his house

loans.name: Fares

texts.en:
Fares is a 47-year-old man who lives in Bekaa, Lebanon, with his wife and their seven children. Fares has owned a butcher shop for 12 years. His shop is very clean. His clients are people from his village. When he first started his business, Fares faced some difficulties because his financial situation was bad.

Fares requests a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop. This is the first time that Fares has requested a loan. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for his shop

loans.name: Tièssiri Group

texts.fr:
Les six (06) membres du groupe Tièssiri ont un âge moyen de 36ans et vivent majoritairement dans des familles polygamiques avec en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles se sont connues dans l’association traditionnelle (Faïda)  de tontine des femmes du quartier bamanan kin de Kirango créée depuis une dizaine d’année. 
Elles font le commerce de produits cosmétiques, du riz, du savon et des détergents.
Après avoir bien remboursé les prêts précédents, le groupe est à son 4ème prêt pour un montant de 600 000FCFA qui  sera utilisé pour acheter  10 cartons de savons et 20 cartons de 100 sachets d’Omo « barikatigui ». Elles s’approvisionnent en ces produits à la foire hebdomadaire de Diamarabougou. Tous ces produits sont vendus au marché de Kirango et de Diamarabougou   au comptant ou à crédit  à  une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes.
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 37 900 FCFA  qui sera utilisé pour payer les frais scolaires des enfants. Elles ont pour  ambition d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce afin de diversifier leurs activités commerciales et préparer petit à petit l’avenir des enfants. 
NB : Ami C. est absente de la photo à cause du décès de son enfant. Des voleurs ont assassiné son enfant à Bamako (capitale du Mali).
texts.en:
The six members of the group Tièssiri average 36 years of age and live for the most part in polygamous families with three children on average. The group members know one another from the tontine (Faïda), a traditional association of women, of the Bamanan Kin district of Kirango that was created a dozen years ago. They do commerce in cosmetics, rice, soap, and detergents.

After having repaid the preceding loans, the group is on its fourth loan in the amount of 600,000 francs CFA that will be used to buy: ten boxes of soap and twenty 100-packet boxes of Omo "barikatigui". These goods are gotten at the weekly fair of Diamarabougou and are sold at the Kirango and Diamarabougou markets, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed mostly of women.

The group members intend to realize an average profit of 37,900 francs to be used for paying the schooling costs of the children. Their ambition is to augment their working capital in order to diversify their commerce and to make a future for the children, little by little. Note: Ami C. is absent from the photo because of the death of her child, who was murdered by thieves in Bamako (capital of Mali).

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy soap (in bars and powdered)

loans.name: Hun

texts.en:
Mrs. Hun N., 27, and her husband, Mr. Than Ros, 28, live in a small village across the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They married in 2002 and have one young daughter.

Hun has been a silk weaver for fourteen years, a skill she learned from a nearby villager. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell at market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a truck driver for eight years.

Hun is requesting her first loan of US$ 150 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving

loans.name: Lam

texts.en:
Mrs. Lam M., 44, and her husband, Mr. Bunthoeun Thorn, 53, who live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1990 and have three children: two sons who are in school and one daughter who is a silk weaver.

Lam has been a silk weaver for 29 years. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been selling grocery items for two years. He buys them in Phnom Penh for selling at his home.
