Lam is requesting the loan of US$ 500 to purchase grocery items for her husband to sell and to buy silk material for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for re-sale and buy silk material for her weaving business

loans.name: Radah

texts.en:
Radah is a 40-year-old woman who lives in Bekaa, Lebanon, with her husband and their two children. Radah has been working as a hairdresser. She requests a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua in order to do a whole new decoration for her salon. Her clients are people from her village.

When she first started her business, she used to work at home, which wasn’t easy for her and more tiring, because she also used to go to the houses of her clients. Radah decided on starting her own business because of her experience.

This is her second loan and she has always paid on time. Her previous loan has influenced her life in a good way.

loans.use: Redecorate her beauty salon

loans.name: Alena

texts.en:
Alena is divorced and has two children. She sells newspapers and magazines at a store located downtown where she rents space. Alena has been in this business for 5 years. She began it after she divorced her husband, because she needed a source of income that could provide for her and her children.

Now, the business is going well. Alena has got repeat customers who buy newspapers and such from her. Moreover, her good location brings in more and more new customers.

Alena would like to receive a loan of 8,000 UAH to increase her inventory. The loan would allow her to almost double the assortment and be able to increase her audience. Alena uses any additional profit to help her children to pay their college tuition.

loans.use: to increase her inventory

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth O. is 51 years old and married with 7 children. She has a patent medicine shop where she sells medicine to her customers. She is requesting the loan amount of N80,000  to purchase more medicine to sell. She says thanks to Kiva and all lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine for re-sale

loans.name: Socheat

texts.en:
Mrs. Socheat P., 37, and her husband, Mr. Leap Chab, 34, who live along National Road Number One about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1995 and have two sons. Both of them are in local school.

Socheat has been a garment factory worker for four years. Her husband has been a wooden house builder for ten years. They hope that their businesses will be able to support their children's further education. The family lives in an old house and part of it is broken but they lack the money to repair it.

Therefore, Socheat is requesting her first loan of US$ 1000 to repair her house.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Korotimi

texts.fr:
Madame Korotimi Traoré est âgée de  44 ans, mariée elle vit avec son mari et ses 5 enfants  dans une grande  famille traditionnelle avec d’autres ménagers dans le quartier Sécoura de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant abandonné l’école  pour  des raisons sociales, elle commence très tôt à mener les activités commerciales. Après avoir  mené plusieurs, elle  finit par  embrasser le métier de teinturière. Initiée par l’ONG ALPHALOG, son apprentissage a pris  3 ans. Elle mène cette activité depuis 13 ans et jouit d’une grande notoriété. Elle participe aux foires et expositions nationales et internationales. Elle est membre de la coordination régionale des artisans de Ségou, présidente de la fédération nationale des artisans du Mali (FENAM), vice présidente du réseau des femmes artisanes d’Afrique de l’ouest. Elle jouit également d’une grande clientèle diverse et variée, elle reçoit des  commandes  de partout.
Elle  est en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis 42 mois. Après  3 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels tous bien remboursés, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel.
Ce prêt   sera  utilisé pour acheter, 50 pagnes de tissus, 5 cartons d’eau de javel et 2 cartons de savons. Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières sur place.
Madame Korotimi Traoré vend lors des expositions, foires, festivals et au centre culturel Sinignesigui de Sécoura. Elle effectue ses ventes   au comptant et à crédit. Sa clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes, nationaux et étrangers.
Avec ce prêt, elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 200 000 FCFA, ce dernier lui permettra d’aider d’autres personnes surtout les filles en déperdition scolaire. Son rêve est de créer une entreprise dans le domaine de l’habillement.
texts.en:
Ms. Korotimi Traoré, age 44, is married and lives with her husband and children in a large traditional family with other households in the Sécoura district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having dropped out of school for social reasons, she started early on working in commerce. After doing several kinds of work, she ended up embracing dyes and tinting as a trade. With training from the non-governmental organization ALPHALOG, her apprenticeship took three years.

She has working in this trade for thirteen years and enjoys a great reputation. She participates in national and international fairs and expositions and is a member of the regional coordination of Ségou artisans of Mali (FENAM) and is the vice-president of the women artisans network of West Africa. She also enjoys a large, diverse, and varied customer base and receives special orders from all over.

She has had an association with Soro Yiriwaso for 42 months. After three solidarity loans and two individual loans, all repaid, she is on her third individual loan. The loan will be used to buy 50 lengths of cloth, 5 boxes of bleach, and 2 boxes of soap. She gets her basic supplies locally. Sales are made at expositions, fairs, festivals, and at the cultural center Sinignesigui de Sécoura. Cash or credit is accepted from customers composed of men and women, national and foreign.

With this loan, she intends to realize a monthly profit of 200,000 francs CFA, which will enable her to help other people, especially girls in need of schooling. Her dream is to create an enterprise in the clothing sector.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basic supplies for dyes and tinting

loans.name: Hasary

texts.en:
Mr. Hasary M., 26, and his wife, Mrs. Afiny Kob, 26, married in 2001 and have two daughters. Both of them are still too young to go to school. The family lives along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Hasary and his wife have been fishing for three months. They fish in the Mekong River about 500 meters from their house and earn about US$ 5 a day. Before this business, Hasary used to be a construction worker and selling personal beauty products but because that business was not so good he quit his selling and started his fishing during this fishing season. Hasary is requesting a loan of US$ 800 to purchase a boat and motor for his fishing.

loans.use: To purchase a boat and motor for his fishing business

loans.name: Sokhen

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhen K., 50, and her husband, Mr. Ven Yang, 53, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1985 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. One of them is married and lives outside the family house; one daughter is a garment factory worker and another one studies in grade 12.

Sokhen has been selling silk fabrics for four years. She buys them from her villagers for re-sale in Siem Reap province. Her husband has been a farmer since he was young; he grows rice. Sokhen is requesting her first loan of US$ 700 to purchase silk fabrics for re-sale.

loans.use: To purchase silk fabrics for re-sale.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mr. Mao P., 29, and his wife, Mrs. Lyna Eng, 30, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about 17 kilometers from Phnom P., married in 2003 and have one young daughter.

Mao has been a construction worker for three years; it’s a skill he learned from his brother. Besides construction work, he does farming as well. His wife has been a farmer for two years. They grow vegetables and other crops in their farmland in the village. Mao is requesting his first loan of US$ 500 to purchase a water pump for his farming.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump

loans.name: Dara

texts.en:
Mr. Dara C., 28, and his wife, Mrs. Preyvan Vanna, 35, live in a small village off of National Road Number Two about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married for ten years and have seven children: five sons and two daughters. Three of them stay with their aunt in Phnom Penh, two children are in school and another one is still young.

Dara has been driving Motor Remorque taxi (Remorque is a motorbike with a trailer at the back) for eleven years. He carries goods and people from his village to Takhmao and Phnom Phenh and from Takhmao to his village. His wife has been a garment factory worker for six years.

Dara plans to repair his motorbike and trailer because it is very old and broken in some parts so he is requesting a loan of US$ 200 to repair his Remorque.

loans.use: To repair his motorbike and trailer

loans.name: Tharin

texts.en:
Mr. Tharin S., 43, and his wife, Mrs. Voeun Nhem, 44, live in a small village along National Road Number Five about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1983 and have four children: one son and three daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home, one daughter is a garment factory worker and another one attends school.

Tharin has been a fisherman for 26 years, a skill he learned by himself. His wife has been selling fish for 26 years as well. She sells them at Prek Phnao market. Tharin is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase fishing nets and seine for fishing.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets and seine for fishing.

loans.name: Chanthorn

texts.en:
Mr. Chanthorn L., 32, and his wife, Mrs. Sopheap Nhong, 31, were married in 1997 and have four sons. Two of their sons attend school and the other two sons are still young. The family lives in a small village aL. National Road Number Five about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Chanthorn has been driving a motor taxi for twelve years. His wife has been selling lotus flowers since she was married. She buys them from the village where she lives for resale at the market in Phnom Penh. The couple sells rice as well. Chanthorn is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase rice for resale.

loans.use: To purchase rice for resale.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en: Jean is a 27-year-old single man, living in Kherbit Kanafar, in the Bekaa Valey. Jean started working as a farmer with his father six years ago. Jean needs to borrow $1,000 in order to buy seeds, in addition to preparing the land for cultivation.

loans.use: Buy seeds and prepare the land for cultivation

loans.name: Nadine

texts.en: Nadine is a 20-year-old young woman, living in Rachaya in the Bekaa Valley. One year ago, Nadine started her own home-based business. She learned from a friend the art of sewing. Today Nadine is requesting to borrow $1,200 in order to buy new sewing tools and introduce traditional Lebanese handicrafts.

loans.use: Buy new sewing tools

loans.name: Suraiya M. Latif Group

texts.en:
Suraiya baji is a 48-year-old married lady and has resided in a city named Borewala, Paksitan, for the past 13 years. She couldn’t get an education due to her parents' little financial resources. She is married to a man whose name is M. L. and he is a gardener. She is a mother of five children: two sons and three daughters. Her elder son is a mason. Another reads in 2nd standard. Her first two daughters are involved in a carpet weaving business. Her youngest daughter reads in 3rd standard.

Suraiya baji handles a milk selling business independently. She does this work to fulfill the needs of her family, because it’s a difficult task for a single person to serve the family. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo to expand her milk selling business.

She is the group leader of some more women of her locality. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy thread to resell. Rafiqan naz baji wants a loan to buy fertilizer to resell. Mumtaz baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Khursheed baji wants a loan to buy wood to resell. Abida parveen baji wants a loan to buy iron to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for her milk selling business

loans.name: Aychi

texts.en: Ayshi is a 44-year-old woman, living in Kamed Al Lawz in the Bekaa Valley. She has worked for three years as a sales woman specializing in cosmetics. Over the years she managed to attract an increasing number of clients. Today, Aysha wants to borrow $1,200 in order to buy more inventory to satisfy her clients' needs.

loans.use: Buy more inventory

loans.name: Pascaline

texts.en: Pascaline A. is twenty eight years old. She is single, self dependent and owns and operates a beauty saloon in her neighborhood. Pascaline is a very skillful and talented hair dresser who adds a lot of beauty to the hair of her many customers. She says her secret is hard work and good customer service. She believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service, therefore her styles and skills are well known in her area. Pascaline need additional working capital in the form of loan to procure a large quantity of materials; assorted hair creams,  weave-ons, shampoo, activator etc. to service her clients. She is a member of the community group called Mpaebofo (which means prayerful) Trust Group. Bawjiase is the name of the local community which is a suburb of Accra, the capital city. In this loan group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and provide support to each other to repay. She will be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To procure a large quantity of materials- assorted hair creams, weave-ons, shampoo, activator etc.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi A. is 60 years old. She is a divorced wife and mother of five children. Her children are now adults, working and have moved out of the family home. Esi now lives with her three year old grand daughter. She produces “Alata soap” which is a locally made soap; it is widely used by local people for washing and bathing. Alata soap is prepared from palm kernel oil, burnt cocoa pod, and soda. The name “Alata” stands for Nigeria. It is believed that the technology was learned from the Nigerians and by some Ghanaians who once lived in Nigeria. Due to the increase in the price of cocoa pods in the country, she is not able to buy more of the product, and is therefore requesting a loan to buy more raw materials. She hopes to raise her income and use the proceeds to employ people to help her produce her soap. She is a member of the community group called Special Trust Group. The name of her community is Bawjiase, a suburb of Accra, the capital city of Ghana. In her group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and provide support to each to handle repayment.

loans.use: To buy cocoa pods, palm kernel oil and soda in bulk.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John A. is a local manufacturer. He is 48 years old, married and has six children. Currently, five of his children are in school. He lives with his family in Bawjiase, near Accra, the capital city of Ghana. John is a blacksmith and manufactures hoes, cutlasses, sickles which he sells in nearby market squares to the local farmers. He is not able to meet his customers demand due to insufficient working capital. The costs of his working tools and materials have also risen considerably. John requests a loan to purchase raw materials such as metal plates, an anvil, blower, Bedford frame, hammer etc. to scale up production and meet demand. He hopes to raise more income and use the proceeds to expand his business and also support his family. He is a member of the community group called Special Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan and provide assistance to one another to handle repayment.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials such as metal plates, an anvil, blower, Bedford frame, hummer etc.

loans.name: Roland

texts.en:
Roland I. is 30 years old and married with 3 children. His wife sells fruits such as oranges, pineapples and apples. Roland has a shop where he sells and rent out CD’s and VCD’s. He lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. 

He is requesting for a loan in the amount of N80,000 to purchase more CD’s and VCD’s to sell. He says thanks to Kiva and all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more CD’s and VCD’s to sell

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina F. is thirty four years old, married and a mother of three children. Her kids are in school. She lives with her family in a rented apartment in Bawjiase, a suburb of Accra, the capital city of Ghana. Augustina loves trading, the business through which she earns bread for her family. She is a petty trader, who trades in cassava, yams, plantain, maize, etc. She sells in the community market. She treks to the farming communities to procure the foodstuffs and retail to her customers.

Her husband is a taxi driver in the Bawjiase community. Augustina’s support of her husband is known from her resourcefulness in food provision for the family and payment of utility bills. She believes education is the best legacy a parent can leave to a child, so matters of her kids' education are of utmost concern to her. She believe she can do better in her business when she is resourced with additional working capital in the form of a loan, which will enable her to purchase more stock to serve her customers. She hopes that she will be able to increase her income and save more to finance her kids' schooling.

She is a member of a community group called Special Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and provide assistance to one another in handling repayment.

loans.use: To purchase cassava, yams, plantain, maize, etc. in bulk.

loans.name: Julie Amen

texts.en: Julie O. is 32 years old and married with 4 children. She sells cooked foods to support her family and she plans to increase her sales by increasing her stock. She is requesting the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah T. is thirty years old. She is married with three kids who are currently in school. Hannah is a trader and loves selling. She sells food stuffs like cassava dough, corn dough and maize in the local market of Bawjiase where she lives. Cassava and corn dough are produced by milling fresh cassava and maize to obtain the main ingredient for banku, one of the popular Ghanaian diets. Selling for the past five years, she has lots of experience in winning customers.

Hannah is an achiever and her focus is to save enough to provide her kids with quality education for their future careers. With the loan, she wants to purchase increased stock of cassava and maize to produce both cassava and corn dough to satisfy her customers’ needs. She is a member of the borrowing group called ‘Maranatha Trust Group'. In this group, members provide support to one another in handling repayment. She does not sell on days of her group meeting and her picture was taken during her group meeting. She would be grateful for that assistance.

loans.use: To purchase cassava and maize in bulk.

loans.name: Annet's Group

texts.en:
Annet N. is the chairperson of the Kalagala Development Group in Mpigi, now seeking its sixth loan from Pearl Microfinance. Both a businesswoman and farmer of many years’ experience, Annet purchases bananas (matooke), beans, and maize for resale in the various area markets and raises poultry and cattle. As well, she grows some matooke, beans and maize for both home consumption and sale.

Annet is the mother of three children, one of whom is still in school, and also the caregiver for five orphans who all attend school. She says she has been successful in her business ventures because of the help and unqualified support of her children and husband.

Previous loans have also been instrumental in the success of her poultry business, enabling her to buy feed and day-old chicks in bulk. Annet is now requesting a loan to assist in the purchase of 300 more layers and 200 more broilers.

loans.use: To purchase day-old chicks, both broilers and layers, for her farm expansion.

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en:
Joshua A. is 24 years old. He is single and independent. Joshua lives alone in a rented apartment in Bawjiase community near Accra. Most of the inhabitants of Bawjiase are either in farming or buy and sell farm products. Very few people run different types of business. John is a trader and trades in pork. He buys the pigs from the northern part of the country, dresses them and supplies them to restaurant operators as meat for their meals.

Pork is enjoyed in many Ghanaian homes because the flavor is good and it is quite affordable. His business progress is slow because he has inadequate funds to buy the pigs from the farmers. With the loan, he wants to buy more pigs to serve his customers with good quality pork for their meals. He believes the loan will allow him to better meet the demands of his customers. He is a member of the community group called "Special Trust Group". In this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more pigs to sell for meat

loans.name: Dominico's Group

texts.en:
Dominico M. is a very hard-working and down-to-earth man with various businesses to run. He is a farmer with various crops such sweet potatoes, cassava and yams growing both for sale and for home consumption. He has commercial rental houses from which he earns a monthly income, and he also makes bark cloth for sale. In fact he is well known through out Mpigi and the surrounding areas for making quality products and this has won him many customers.

Dominico now has other construction works going on building rental houses and he needs a loan to be able to complete this construction by buying cement, iron bars, wiring, and paying off his workers and in the end, this will earn him more by renting out these premises.

loans.use: buying construction materials such as cement, bricks, iron bars and timber to finish his rental houses

loans.name: Zenon

texts.es:
Zenon vive en la calle “ K ” # 100   de la zona Puerto Mejillones en la ciudad de El Alto.
 
Vive junto a su esposa  y  sus  cinco hijos que van desde los catorce a los tres meses de edad, en su domicilio propio.
 
Trabaja como chofer asalariado de transporte pesado a larga distancia con la republica del Perú, su esposa se dedica a la confección de cubrecamas artesanalmente.
 
El crédito lo destinará en la adquisición de materiales  para la construcción de un techo en el cual actualmente funciona su cocina y habilitarlo para la habitación de uno de sus hijos y mejorar sus condiciones de vida. 
 
Es el primer   crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada lo califica para otorgarle el crédito.
texts.en:
Zenon lives at 100 “K” street, in the region of Puerto Mejillones en the city of El Alto. He lives together with his wife and his five children who range from the age of 14 to 3 months, in his own house. He works as a salary-paid chauffer, tedious from the large distances of Peru. His wife works as an artisan, making bedspreads. This loan will be used for the acquisition of materials for construction of a roof for a room that will double as a functioning kitchen and a bedroom for one of his sons, and to better his living conditions. This is his first loan with Impro, but his completed evaluation warrants granting him the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Matt Capetola, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The construction of a roof over his kitchen that will double as a bedroom for his son.

loans.name: Mary

texts.es:
Mary, vive en la calle Inca Roca  Rio Seco en la ciudad de El Alto.
 
Vive  en la casa de sus padres, Ella es casada y tiene  una hija de dos años, su esposo recientemente consiguió un empleo como vendedor de artefactos eléctricos a comisión.

Se dedica al comercio informal en su puesto callejero en una de las ferias de la ciudad vendiendo ropa interior de señoras. Negocio que se pone en movimiento a partir de las 18 horas. Momento que esta permitido por la Alcaldía para la instalación de dicha feria.



El crédito lo destinara en la compra de mayor cantidad de mercadería (ropa interior de mujer), y así mejorar sus ingresos

Es el primer  crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgar el crédito.
texts.en:
Mary lives on the street Inca Roca, Rio Seco, in the city of El Alto. She lives in her parents’ house. She is married and has a daughter of 2, her husband recently got a job selling electronic parts by commission. Mary sells goods in her location on the street in one of the markets of the city. She sells women’s underwear, a business of 18 hours that she started once she gained permission from the mayors office to install her stand in the market she mentioned. This loan will be used to buy the highest quality merchandise (women’s undergarments) and to improve her business by doing so. This is her first loan with Impro, the evaluation that she completed qualifies her to be granted the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Matt Capetola, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more women's undergarments to sell in a market of El Alto, a city.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George K., twenty-five, is single and independant. George lives alone in a rented apartment in Bawjiase community near Accra. Most of the inhabitants of Bawjiase are either in farming or buy and sell in farm products. Very few people run different types of businesses. George is a merchant and sells in soft drinks. He sells varieties of drinks and mineral water in both bottles and cans, such as Coca Cola, Fanta, pineapple juice, Sprite, etc.

George orders the drinks directly from the manufacturers in Accra where the cost is economical. He believes he can scale up his business with additional working capital so he wants a loan to order more drinks and mineral water so that he can distribute to a larger number of customers. He is a member of "Maranatha Trust Bank" group. The members in the group guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan and provide assistance to one another in handling repayment.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Jameo's Group

texts.en:
Jameo N., commonly known as ‘Hajat,’ is the chairperson of Mumuwa development group in Mpigi. She has been a poultry farmer ever since she joined her lending group and she is happy that she has been able to sustain herself and her business all this while.

Jameo also buys agricultural products such as avocadoes, yellow bananas, jackfruit, oranges, and mangoes from farmers in and around her village and takes them to Kampala for sale. This is a seasonal business and profitable since there is a ready market for all that she takes for sale. Jameo has booked more layers and broilers from a poultry farm hence she needs a loan to be able to pay up the balance and also buy start-up feed for the chickens. She is grateful for the loans because they have made her who she is today.

loans.use: pay for the day-old chicks that she has ordered as well as stocking feed for them

loans.name: Marcelino

texts.es:
Marcelino tiene un pequeño carro de carga donde transporta material de construcción y todo tipo de cargas  dentro la ciudad de El Alto, la esposa es comerciante de verduras, tiene un hijo de 21 años de edad que está estudiando en la universidad estatal. Vive en su casa propia ubicada en la zona Villa Tunari de la ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito lo destinará para la compra de motor para su movilidad, para seguir trabajando con su carro que le sirve de herramienta de trabajo.
 
Es el segundo crédito con Kiva, el buen comportamiento de pago que demostró con nuestra institución le permite acceder a otro préstamo.
texts.en:
Marcelino has a small pickup truck with which he transports construction materials and other kinds of cargo. Within the city of El Alto, his wife is a vegetable vendor. He has a son of 21, who is studying in the state university. Marcelino lives in his own house located in the region Villa Tunari in the city of El Alto. This laon will be used to buy a motor for his truck, so that he can continue working with it, because it serves him as a tool for working. This is his second loan with Kiva. He has displayed good payment behavior with our institution, and so he may access another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Matt Capetola, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a motor for his pick up truck to transport construction material and cargo.

loans.name: Alberta

texts.en:
Alberta A. operates an electrical shop in her neighborhood. She started her operation three years ago. She is a 30-year-old mother of two kids who are currently in school. She lives with her family in Bawjiase, a suburb of Accra, the capital city of Ghana, in a family house. Alberta loves commerce, the business through which she earns bread for her family. She buys and sells electrical appliances such as cables, wires, switches, screws, etc. Through her business, she has been very resourceful for her family. She needs additional working capital in the form of a loan to enable her to increase her inventory.

With the loan, she wants to purchase and include more electrical gadgets such as blenders, irons, electric cookers, etc. She also hopes to increase her savings to provide her kids with quality education. She would appreciate it very much if you decide to offer her that assistance. She is a member of the community group called "Special Solidarity" Group. Members in this group guarantee and support one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more electrical gadgets such as blenders, irons, electric cookers, etc

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en: Rachael O. is 57 years old and married with 5 children. She plans to increase her stock to make more profit. She is requesting the loan amount of N 50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Jhonny

texts.es:
El señor Jhonny vive en alquiler con su esposa e hija en la Av. Buenos Aires de la zona de Alto san pedro de la ciudad de La Paz; trabaja como chofer de radio taxi con lo cual mantiene a sus familia y la esposa trabaja como empleada domestica; durante la noche ambos se dedican al comercio según la temporada.
El crédito que solicita es para comprar billetes y canastitas en miniatura para poder vender en la feria de Alasita. Esta feria se caracteriza por la venta de todo tipo de miniaturas.

El historial que mantiene en Impro es bueno por lo tanto puede acceder a un nuevo crédito. Son clientes nuestros desde el año 2007.
texts.en:
Jhonny rents a house with his wife and daughter on Avenue Buenos Aires in the region of El Alto known as San Pedro de la Ciudad de La Paz. He works as a radio-taxi driver, a job with which he can maintain his family. His wife works in domestic services. During the night both work according to season. The loan that he asks for is to buy tickets and miniature baskets to sell in the fair of Alasita. This market is known specifically for selling all types of miniatures. Jhonny maintains good past relations with Impro, and so he is permitted to ask for another loan. They have been clients of ours since year 2007.

Translated from Spanish by Matt Capetola, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy miniatures to be sold in the fair of Alasitas.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson O. is 46 years old, married, and has two children. Currently both his children are in school. He lives with his family in Bawjiase, near Accra, the capital city of Ghana. Samson is a blacksmith and manufactures hoes, cutlasses, and sickles which he sells in nearby market squares to local farmers. He is not able to meet his customers' demand due to inadequate working capital.

The cost of his work tools and materials has also risen considerably. Samson is requesting a loan to purchase raw materials such as metal plates, an anvil, a blower, a Bedford frame, hummer, etc. to scale up production to meet demand. He hopes to raise more income and use the proceeds to expand his business and also support his family. He is a member of the community group called "Special Trust Group". In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and provide assistance to one another to handle repayment.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials such as metal plates, an anvil, a blower, a Bedford frame, hummer, etc.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia O. is 55 years old and married with 5 children. She sells drinks and fried meat. She hopes to expand her business. She is requesting the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Products for her retail shop such as a sack of beans, maize, books, pens, and pencils

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort A. is forty-four years old. She is married and has five children. Two of her children are in training college, one is a nurse, and the last two are in primary school. She lives with her family in Bawjiase community, near Accra, the capital city of Ghana, in a family house. She works very hard to help her husband take care of the family.

Comfort is a tomato seller. Comfort says she purchases tomatoes from the local tomato farmers in their farms and transports them to her location. This strategy helps her to avoid middlemen who buy from the farmers and distribute to merchants at profit.

Comfort sells her tomatoes to food vendors and other consumers in and around her locality. She wants to increase her working capital so that she can purchase tomatoes in bulk on a trip. She believes she can achieve more progress and make increased profit and conveniently support her family and pay for her kids’ education. She also believes in education and matters of her kids’ education are of utmost concern to her. She is a member of group called “Maranatha” Trust Bank in her community. The group members guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan and provide assistance to one another in handling repayment.

loans.use: To purchase tomatoes in bulk

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose A. is 38 years old and married with 2 children. She sells foodstuffs such as crayfish, melons, palm oil, etc. She hopes to increase her sales. She is requesting the loan amount of N 50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret T. is 41 years old. She is a wife and the mother of three kids. Margaret loves sellingCurrently, all her kids are in school. She lives with her family in Bawjiase community, near Accra, the capital city of Ghana, in a family house. She works very hard to help her husband take care of the family. Her husband sells hardware.

Margaret loves selling goods, the business through which she obtains a daily source of livelihood. She has been selling cassava for seven years to support her family. Cassava is one of the favorite staple foods that supply carbohydrate components in people's diets. It is mostly used in preparation of local dishes like “fufu” and “banku”.

Margaret takes delivery of goods from farmers who provide her with direct supply. This enables her to avoid middlemen who would buy from the farmers and resell to her at higher prices. With this loan, she wants to purchase cassava in bulk to serve her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to pay for her kids'n schooling. Margaret is a member of a community group called "Maranatha Trust Group". In this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans.

loans.use: To purchase cassava in bulk

loans.name: Dezi's Group

texts.en:
Dezi N. is the chairperson of "Bbogo Women’s Group" in Lugazi. She is a farmer growing bananas ‘matooke’ (a kind of banana), potatoes, and maize plantations on her family piece of land which food is both for sale and home consumption. In addition to farming, she prepares local brew known as "waragi" for sale, using a certain kind of yellow banana which she has also planted on the same family land.

Dezi is 42 years old and married with 10 children of whom 6 are girls and 4 are boys, while she cares for 5 grand-children. The loans have helped Dezi plus her other members in the group to recapitalize their businesses and this time round, Dezi would like a loan to buy more bananas for making "waragi" enough for her customers, as well as employing labour / manpower on her farm since now is the beginning of the rainy season. She is grateful for all her previous loans from Pearl Microfinance; for she is a better person now both in business and in family.

loans.use: buying more bananas for making her local brew and paying for manpower for her farm

loans.name: Stanley

texts.en: Stanley N., 30 years old and single, sells wine. He is requesting a loan to purchase more wine, hoping to expand his business. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more wine to sell.

loans.name: Oussèye

texts.fr: Oussèye B. agée de 32 ans est divorcée avec 01 enfant en charge. Elle est membre du banc villageois de Némataba depuis 5 ans et demi.Son activité est le commerce de grained'arachide. Elle veut acheter des sacs de 100 kg, payer le transport pour ensuite revendre.Le prêt qu'elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance
texts.en:
Oussèye B., age 32, is divorced and has a child to support. She has been a member of the village council of Némataba for five and a half years. She does commerce in peanuts and wants to use this loan to buy 100-kg sacks, to pay for transport, and then offer them for retail sale. The loan she is requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanuts for resale

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa A. is a fifty-year-old widowed mother of three children, two girls who are currently in high school and a boy in primary school. They live in the community of Bawjiase, near Accra, in the family house.

An industrious lady, Yaa operates a cold store in the local market square selling fresh fish purchased wholesale from larger establishments in Accra. She has been operating this business for 12 years and is now requesting a loan to buy the goods in bulk and acquire bigger refrigerators. Yaa hopes to increase her profit margin to enable her save more to support her family, especially her children’s education. Education is of utmost concern to her as she believes it is the best legacy a parent can leave a child.

Yaa is a member of a bank trust group called Special, whose members guarantee the repayment of each other’s loans.

loans.use: To purchase fresh fish in bulk.

loans.name: Eva Josefina

texts.es: Doña Eva Josefina P. T. cuenta con 31 años de edad, del Caserío Xetinimit, Aldea Nimasac, del departamento de Totonicapán, Guatemala, casada, con dos hijos, se dedica a la Artesanía como confeccionista de ropa típica para mujeres, debido a que no cuenta con las maquinas de coser suficientes, se acerco a la Asociación ASDIR  a solicitar un préstamo para la compra de una máquina industrial para poder mejorar su trabajo y satisfacer la demanda de los clientes teniendo la oportunidad de aumentar sus ingresos y como también ampliar su capital, dándole una mejor condición de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Eva Josefina Perez T., 31, lives in the Guatemalan "departamento" of Totonicapan. She's married and has two children. She operates a business making and selling traditional clothing for women. Because she can't rely on the sewing machines that she has, she's approached Asociacion ASDIR to apply for a loan that she will use to buy an industrial sewing machine so that she can improve her work and meet the demand of her customers. This is her chance to increase both her income and her capital so that her family will ultimately have a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy industrial sewing machine.

loans.name: Adiaratou

texts.fr:
Adiaratou traoré est âgée de 24 ans, célibataire sans enfant, elle vit chez ses parents  dans le quartier Sogomougou de la ville de koutiala ( région de Sikasso ). Elle  n’a pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école, Adiaratou  a été élévée par sa grande mère qui faisait de la restauration, donc elle a appris cette activité auprès de cette dernière depuis son jeune âge et l’exerce actuellement pour elle même il y a 7 ans. Très ambitieuse et couragieuse, son lieu de vente est la convergeance des ouvriers et des charettiers de la ville. Pour satisfaire sa clientèle et augmenter la taille de son activité, elle décida de rejoindre  l ‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il ya un mois. Elle est à son 1er prêt  individuel.  Comme nous sommes à la fin des récoltes et que les céréales coûtent moins cher, Adiaratou  compte acheter  10 sacs de  50  kg de haricot  pour le stocker, 5 cartons de spaguetty, et des condiments alimentaires. Elle s’approvisionne auprès des producteurs de céréales au grand marché de Koutiala ,et    elle vend ses aliments  préparés au grand marché  à une clientèle composée généralement d’hommes et quelques femmes  au comptant, et à crédit
Elle espère  réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 75.000FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans d’autres activités génératrices de revenus.    
 Son ambition est d’ouvrir un grand restaurant  dans la ville de Koutiala.
texts.en:
Adiaratou Traoré, age 24, is unmarried and has no children. She lives at her parents' place in the Sogomougou district of the city of Koutiala (Sikasso region). She didn't have the chance to go to school, and was raised by her grandmother, who used to sell meals. Adiaratou thus learned at an early age how to do this from her and has been doing so on her own for seven years. A very ambitious and courageous woman, her sales location is where the city's workers and cart handlers converge.

To satisfy her customers and expand her business, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso a month ago and is on her first individual loan. Now that the harvest has come to an end, and grain is less expensive, she plans to buy ten 50-kg sacks of beans to store away, five boxes of spaghetti, and some condiments. Supplies are gotten from grain growers at the Koutiala marketplace. She sells prepared foods at the grand market to customers composed generally of men and a few women, cash or credit accepted.

She hopes to realize an average profit of 75,000 francs CFA per month that will be used to pay the loan interest and to invest the rest in other income-generating work. Her ambition is to open a big restaurant in the city of Koutiala.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beans, spaghetti, and various condiments

loans.name: Grupo Las Flores Group

texts.es:
Este es el grupo Las Flores es originario de la comarca Palo Quemado que pertenece al municipio de Diriomo, está compuesto por tres integrantes : Rosa del Carmen O. R., Sadia Isabel M. M., Araceli de los Ángeles S. L.., son mujeres trabajadoras y humildes.
Doña Rosa del Carmen de 35 años, una mujer joven que vende refrescos, helados, enchiladas, etc.; los elabora y vende  en su casa, tiene clientes de su comunidad. Es casada, su esposo es trabajador del campo, tiene 4 hijos en edad escolar que estudian en la escuela cercana. 
Tiene 5 años de dedicarse a esta actividad desde que compró su refrigeradora y pensó en apoyar a su esposo en los gastos. Además va a vender golosinas y surtir su negocio para un día poder llegar a tener una pulpería, sueña ver un negocio instalado que atienda a la comunidad.
texts.en:
The group Las Flores (The Flowers) are natives of the Palo Quemado region in the Diriomo municipality. The group is comprised of 3 members: Rosa del Carmen O. R., Sadia Isabel M. M. and Araceli de los Ángeles S. L. who are humble and hard-working women. Mrs. Rosa del Carmen is 35 years old, a young woman who sells soft drinks, ice cream, enchiladas, etc. which she make and sell in her home to clients in her community. She is married and her husband works in the field. They have 4 school age children that study in a nearby school. It has been 5 years since she bought her refrigerator and thought to help support her husband with the expenses. She is going to add the sale of snacks and supply her business for a day when she will be able to have a store installed to cater to the community.

Translated from Spanish by Jeanette Chase, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The loan is needed to buy fruit, perishables, bags, etc.

loans.name: Rosas Blancas Group

texts.es:
En L. ciudad D. El Alto se encuentra ubicado el centro focal Los Andes, a éste pertenece L. asociación “Rosas Blancas” .Un grupo muy simpático y particular ya que además D. trabajar juntas D. manera muy responsable, llegaron a formar una muy linda amistad entre ellas. Varias son las actividades del grupo, por ejemplo se dedican a L. venta D. mochilas, venta D. chamarras, venta D. madera, otros miembros D. L. asociación tiene carpinterías.
L. asociación Rosas Blancas  necesita comprar  materia prima para ampliar sus ventas, así sus ingresos mejorarían para el bien D. sus familias.
texts.en:
The Los Andes center is located in the city of El Alto. The Rosas Blancas (White Roses) association is a part of this center. They are pleasant and unique members who, asiD. from collaborating responsibly, have also come to form a beautiful friendship with each other. The group members partake in several business activities, such as selling backpacks, jackets and lumber, while other members have their own carpenter’s workshops.

The Rosas Blancas association needs to purchase raw materials in order to boost sales and, consequently, their earnings for the good of their families.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase raw materials

loans.name: Korotoumou

texts.fr:
Mariée et mère de deux enfants, Mme Korotoumou est âgée de 31 ans, et vit dans une famille monogamique avec son époux et ses enfants dans le quartier Wala-Wala de la préfecture de koutiala ( région de Sikasso ). 
Pour des raisons sociales, Korotoumou n’a pas eu la chance de continuer ses études primaires, pour cela elle s’initia aux activités génératrices de revenus depuis à bas âge. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, elle finit par opter pour l’chat- vente des fruits et légumes depuis maintenant 10 ans. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle  en qualité et  en quantité, elle décida de  faire recours à  l ‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il ya 3 ans. Après  5 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe ) tous correctement remboursés,  elle est à son 1er prêt  individuel. 
Avec ce prêt, elle compte acheter 10 paniers de banane,  5 paniers de papaye et autres. Elle s’approvisionne dans les différentes foires hebdomadaires des villages environnants de koutiala, et effectue sa vente au comptant et à credit au grand marché de koutiala  à une clientèle constituée de femmes et hommes.  
Elle compte  réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 70.000FCFA par mois qu’elle envisage utiliser pour  le remboursement des intérêts,  participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et investir le reste dans d’autres activités génératrices de revenus.
texts.en:
Married and the mother of two children, Ms. Korotoumou is 31 years old and lives in a monogamous family with her husband and children in the Wala-Wala district of Koutiala prefecture (Sikasso region). For social reasons, she did not have the chance to continue in primary school. And so she started working to earn an income at a young age. After having done several kinds of work unsuccessfully, she chose in the end to do commerce in fruit and vegetables ten years ago.

To satisfy customer demands for quality and quantity, she decided to turn towards the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After five solidarity loans (group loans), all correctly repaid, she is on her first individual loan. With this loan, she plans to buy 10 baskets of bananas, 5 baskets of papayas, and more. Supplies are gotten from the different weekly fairs of the villages surrounding Koutiala. She makes her sales, cash or credit accepted, at the grand marketplace of Koutiala, to customers composed of women and men.

She intends to realize an average profit of 70,000 francs CFA per month that she envisions using to repay the loan interest, to help cover day-to-day family expenses, and to invest the rest in other income-generating work.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Oumarou

texts.fr:
Natif de Gao ce jeune célibataire de 30 ans, sans enfant  vit chez ses parents au quartier  N’Tonasso de la ville de koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Oumarou abandonna l’école au niveau secondaire(collège) dû à des raisons sociales. Après avoir tenté beaucoup d’activités tels, ouvrier à l’usine de fabrique d’huile de graines de coton( FAMAB ), la vente ambulantoire, il opta finalement pour l’ouverture d’un magasin de location des baffles(hauts parleurs) et les jeux téléchargés il y’a 3 ans. Seul à mener cette activité de jeux téléchargés, Oumarou ne parvient pas a satisfaire toutes sa clientèle. C’est ainsi qu’il sollicita le concours de l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso seulement un mois pour la satisfaction des besoins de sa clientèle. IL est à son premier prêt  indivduel .
 IL compte acheter  avec ce prêt  un jeu play station et des cassettes DVD. Les cassettes pourront être louée ou vendues .Sa clientèle est composée essentiellement d’enfants,  de femmes et  d’hommes.
Avec l’achat du nouveau jeu , Oumarou espère réaliser  75.000FCFA par mois qu’il utilisera  pour  le remboursement des intérêts de Soro Yiriwaso, et investir le reste dans son activité .
texts.en:
A native of Gao, this young man, 30 years old, unmarried and without children, lives at this parents' place in the N’Tonasso district of the city of Koutiala (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). He left middle school due to social reasons. After having tried many kinds of work, such as working in a cotton seed oil factory (FAMAB) and selling door-to-door, he finally opted three years ago to open a store for renting out loud speakers and for downloaded games.

In regard to his game business only, he has not been able to satisfy all his customers. This is why he requested the assistance of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso just a month ago. He is on his first individual loan, which he plans to use to buy a PlayStation, cassettes, and DVDs. The cassettes could be rented out or sold. His customers are composed essentially of children, women, and men.

With the purchase of new games, he hopes to realize 75,000 francs CFA per month that he will use to repay the Soro Yiriwaso loan interest and to invest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy electronics (games) and cassettes

loans.name: Maria Marcelina

texts.es: La señora María Marcelina R. B., de 31 años de edad, madre soltera,  vive en el Paraje Chuorton, Cantón Chuixchimal del departamento de Totonicapán, Guatemala; ella se dedica al Comercio  (compra y venta de ropa típica) debido a la demanda de sus clientes acudió a la asociación ASDIR a solicitar un préstamo con el cual ella aumentará su capital y así cubrir la demanda de sus clientes; y de esa manera aprovechar la oportunidad que se le está presentando para poder cubrir sus necesidades y darle una mejor condición de vida a su hijo.
texts.en:
Señora Maria Marcelina R. B. is 31 years old and a single mother. She lives in Paraje Chuorton in the town of Chuixchimal in the state of Totonicapan in Guatemala. She buys and sells native clothes. Due to high demand, she decided to apply for a loan through the association ASDIR. She will use this loan to increase capital and inventory. This way she hopes to take advantage of this opportunity and to make a profit so that she can take care of her neccessities and provide a better way of life for her son.

Translated from Spanish by Carolina Zelaya-Kronlund, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase capital

loans.name: Cristal Group

texts.es:
En la zona de Villa Exaltación, se encuentra ubicado el centro focal del mismo nombre, a este pertenece la asociación “cristal” Un grupo muy simpático y particular formado por doce miembros, trabajan de manera organizada hace varios años.  Las actividades que realiza la asociación Cristal, son de todo tipo, Martha por ejemplo tiene una tienda de lubricantes, otras se dedican a la venta de verdura; venta de ropa americana; artefactos electrónicos; ropa usada, otras elaboran jugos en base a la quinua.
Afirman que necesitan mayor capital para la compra de materia prima e insumos (dependiendo el caso), para  poder ampliar sus negocios y generar mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
The Villa Exaltación center is located in an area with the same name. The Cristal association, which belongs to this center, is comprised of twelve very pleasant members who have been working in an organized manner for several years. The Cristal association members partake in different types of business activities. Martha, for example, has her own motor oil shop, while other members sell vegetables, American apparel, electronics, used clothing and homemade, bottled quinoa juice.

They state that they need more work capital in order to purchase supplies and raw materials (depending on each business) in order to expand their businesses and generate more income.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies and raw materials

loans.name: Safiatou

texts.fr:
Mme Safiatou D. est une veuve âgée de 41 ans qui vit dans une famille polygame avec sa coépouse et leurs enfants dans le quartier Wala-Wala de la ville  de koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Son enfance a été perturbée par des problèmes familiaux qui lui ont empêché  d’étudier. Pour parvenir à satisfaire ses besoins, elle n’a pas  pris du temps pour se lancer dans les activités génératrices de revenus notamment la vente des poissons fumés qu’elle aprit au près de ses amies il y a 25 ans. Les poissons fumés sont les plus prisés au milieu Miniaka puisqu’ils sont moins cher(que la viande ou la volaille) et que la majorité de la population est pauvre. 
Afin d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire, elle décida de  rejoindre 
 l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il ya 4 ans. Après  6 prêts en solidaire ( prêt de groupe ) tous remboursés sans difficulté, elle est à son 2ème prêt en individuel dont le prémier  à été perturbé par le décès de son  époux, mais tout de même remboursé entièrement.
Elle compte acheter, 10 paniers de poissons fumés  à Korientzé( Région de Mopti ) auprès des  pêcheurs  Bozo  et  Somonô , et effectue sa vente au  marché poisson de koutiala  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes  au comptant et à credit.
Elle compte  réaliser un bénéfice de 90.000FCFA par mois qu’elle utilisera  pour  le remboursement des intérêts de Soro Yiriwaso et investir le reste dans  certaines charges de la  famille. Son ambition est de diversifier son activité après la mort de son  mari afin de pouvoir correctement prendre en charge les frais de scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. Safiatou D. is a 41-year-old widow who lives in a polygamous family, together with her co-wife and their children, in the Wala-Wala neighborhood in Koutiala (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Her childhood was affected by family problems, which prevented her from studying. To be able to provide for herself, she didn't take long to start money-making businesses, notably the sale of dried fish, that she learned from friends 25 years ago. Dried fish is the most sought-after in her community where most people are poor, since it's cheaper than meat or chicken. To increase her revenues, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso four years ago. After six solidarity loans (group loan), all repaid without problems, she's now seeking her second individual loan. The first one was affected by her husband's death, but was fully repaid anyway. She intends to buy 10 baskets of dried fish in Korientzé (Mopti Region), from Bozo and Somonô fishermen. She sells it for cash or on credit at the fish market in Koutiala, to a clientele composed of women and men. She intends to turn a monthly profit of XOF 90'000 (ca USD$ 180), to be used to repay the loan. The remainder will be invested into some family expenses. Her ambition is to diversify her business after her husband's death, to be able to correctly provide for her children's school expenses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell dried fish

loans.name: Grupo El Flamingo Group

texts.es:
Este es el grupo Flamingo es originario de el municipio de Catarina, está compuesto por tres integrantes: Mercedes Amanda A., Elia María S. G., Rosa del Carmen H. A., mujeres amigas y vecinas, decidieron integrar el grupo para obtener el financiamiento y salir adelante.
Doña Rosa del Carmen, mujer de 42 años de edad, madre de 4 hijos adolescentes de los cuales todos estudian en la escuela del municipio, su actividad es elaborar y vender canastos, en el negocio participan ella, sus hijos y su esposo, la señora vende los canastos en el mercado Oriental de Managua, pero el taller está en su casa de habitación. Esta actividad la aprendió de sus padres que tenían este mismo negocio. El crédito lo necesita para comprar bambú en varas, este lo compra en fincas de Nandaime, en las faldas de el cerro Bombacho, para hacer este viaje tiene que contratar vehículo para traerlos a su casa, en ocasiones tiene que pagar el lote de cañas por adelantado.
texts.en:
The group Flamingo are natives of the Catarina municipality and has 3 members: Mercedes Amanda A., Elia María S. G., Rosa del Carmen H. A.. These women are friends and neighbors who decided to form a group to obtain financing and move forward. Mrs. Rosa del Carmen is 42 years old and is the mother of 4 adolescent children, all of whom study in the municipal school. She makes and sells baskets and her children and husband participate in the business. She sells the baskets in the Oriental de Managua market, but her workshop is a room in her house. She learned this activity from her parents who had the same business. The loan is need to buy bamboo canes which she buys from Nandaime farms in the foothills of Bombacho and for this trip she has hire a vehicle to bring them home and occasionally she has to pay for a lot of canes in advance.

Translated from Spanish by Jeanette Chase, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi D., the 35-year-old mother of two children, both students, lives with her family in a rented apartment in Bawjiase, a suburb of Accra. Her husband is a taxi driver. To support the household, she sells foodstuffs such as plantains and cassava obtained from area farming communities to loyal customers in the neighborhood as well as in the market squares of the nearby cities of Accra and Koforidua.

The sale of these products is very lucrative, and Esi now wants to expand her inventory so as to improve her income to better support the family. Esi is a member of the Maranatha Trust Group, whose members guarantee each other’s loans.

loans.use: To purchase cassava and plantains in bulk.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es: Antonia de 45 años, vive con su hija de 14 años ya que se separó de su esposo, tiene su casa propia, la cual le costó mucho adquirir. Levantándose a las 5 de la mañana, con los primeros rayos del sol, Antonia comienza su día elaborando ladrillos, este es el negocio de la familia y ya lleva 15 años en este trabajo, que requiere de mucho sacrificio y esfuerzo físico. Ella sabe que su trabajo paga los estudios de su hijo, es por eso que le pone todas sus ganas y lo hace tan bien que sus ladrillos son los más vendidos de la zona y aunque tiene dificultades con la adquisición de los materiales, se las ingenia para tenerlos siempre a la mano y no le falte nada. Este octavo préstamo consecutivo, demuestra la confianza que Antonia tiene en Microfinanzas PRISMA, y sabe que cumplirá con sus pagos como lo hace siempre. Planea invertir el dinero solicitado en la elaboración de sus ladrillos, para de esta manera hacer crecer su producción y brindarle a su hijo una mejor vida.
texts.en:
Antonia is a 45-year-old woman who lives with her 14-year-old son because she is estranged from her husband. She has her own house, which was difficult for her to obtain. Waking up with the first sun rays at 5 am, Antonia starts her day making bricks. This is her family business in which she has participated for 15 years. Her job requires a lot of sacrifice and physical strain. However, she knows that it pays for her son’s education, which is why she gives it her all. She does her job so well that hers are the best-selling bricks in the area. Even though she has difficulty obtaining raw materials, she figures out ways to obtain them and not lack anything. This is her eighth consecutive loan, which demonstrates Antonia’s trust in Microfinanzas PRISMA. She knows that she will repay her loan as she has always done. She plans to invest the loan in making bricks so that she can increase production and provide her son with a better life.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials to make bricks

loans.name: Jiguitougou (L’Espoir) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Jiguitougou  est un regroupement de quatre femmes du   quartier medina-koura de la ville de Koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali) qui sont  des voisines de longue date. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans, mariées et mères d’au moins 4 enfants chacune. 
Elles mènent essentiellement les activités de coiffure (tresses) et la vente de mèches. Le service des femmes du groupe Jiguitougou est très apprécié sollicité par les grandes dames de la ville de Koutiala et elles ont de l’expérience dans leur secteur d’activité et évoluent avec  la mode.
Dans l’objectif d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont intégré le programme  crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis 5 ans. Ces femmes du groupe Jiguitougou sont à leurs  neuvième prêts solidaires après avoir remboursé sans difficulté les huit premiers. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des cartons de mèches à Lomé et les revendre aux clientes qui viennent se tresser et à d’autres très généralement au comptant mais quelques fois à crédit.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 160 000 CFA. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et contribuer dans la prise en charge des dépenses courantes de la famille. Dans l’avenir, le groupe Jiguitougou ambitionne d’ouvrir des  boutiques de luxe beauté  et diversifier  leurs activités.
texts.en:
The Jiguitougou group comprises four women living in the Medina-Koura quarter (city of Koutiala, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali), who have been neighbors for a long time. They are married and are, on average 35 years old, and the mother of at least four children each. Their businesses consist mainly in hairdressing (braiding) and selling hair extensions. Their services are very much appreciated and sought-after by the upper-class women of the city of Koutiala. They have a lot of experience in their field, and follow the trends. In view of expanding their businesses, the members of the group joined the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso five years ago. These women are now seeking their ninth solidarity loan, after having repaid the first eight without problems. The new loan will be used to buy boxes of hair extensions in Lomé, and to resell them to customers who are getting their hair braided, and to others, usually for cash but sometimes also on credit. With this new loan, they intend to turn an average profit of XOF 160'000 (ca US$ 320). This profit will be used to repay the loan and to help with the daily family expenses. In the future, the Jiguitougou group ambitions to open luxury beauty shops and to diversify their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell hair extensions

loans.name: Kantutas Group

texts.es: La asociación  “kantutas” pertenece al centro focal Senkata, a la cabeza de Maritza Q., como presidenta  demuestran ser un grupo cumplido y organizado. El mencionado grupo esta formado por doce socias que trabajan  hace más de once años con la entidad de Pro-Mujer. Existen diversas actividades de dentro el grupo, por ejemplo Hilda tiene una tienda de barrio, Celia se dedica a la venta de coca, otras de las socias venden arroz, son carpinteros y también atienden cabinas telefónicas. La asociación Kantutas desea ampliar su ventas, por lo que necesita de mayores créditos para la compra de productos al por mayor, solo con el fin de mejorar sus ganancias para el beneficio de sus familias.
texts.en:
The Kantutas association, headed by group president Maritza Q., is a part of the Senkata center. They are a very responsible and organized group comprised of 12 members who have been working with Pro-Mujer for over eleven years. The members partake in different business activities. For example, Hilda has her own neighborhood general store while Celia sells coca leaves. Other members sell rice, are carpenters, or mind telephone booths at a call shop. The Kantutas association would like to boost sales, which is why they need bigger loans so that they can purchase wholesale products with the aim of increasing earnings for the benefit of their families.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wholesale products

loans.name: Santiago

texts.es: Don Santiago C. V. cuenta con 56 años de edad, casado, con dos hijos vive en el cantón Chuisacmaljá del departamento de Totonicapán, Guatemala. Lleva  cinco años dedicado al Comercio en la compra y venta de zapatos el cual es la fuente de sus ingresos para poder sostener a  su familia, debido al incremento de sus ventas acudió a la asociación ASDIR por un préstamo y así poder cubrir la demanda de sus clientes de la misma manera aumentar su capital y surtir su negocio, aprovechando la ganancia que le generaran las ventas para poder prosperar y así cubrir las necesidades de su familia.
texts.en:
Don Santiago C. V. is 56 years old. He's married and has 2 children. He lives in the town of Chuisacmalja in the state of Totonicapan, Guatemala. He's been buying and selling shoes for the past 5 years. This job is the main source of income for his family. Due to an increase in sales, he decided to get a loan through ASDIR. He will use this loan to purchase more inventory and to meet his clients' high demands. He hopes to make a good profit and to remain successful so that he can take care of the neccessities of his family.

Translated from Spanish by Carolina Zelaya-Kronlund, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase capital

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Married with three children, 33-year-old Leticia W. lives with her family in a rented apartment in Bawjiase, a suburb of Accra, the capital city of Ghana. Her husband is a trader in used clothes, while Leticia has been selling cosmetics and jewelry for the past four years.

Cosmetics sales are a lucrative source of income, and her experience in the community market has earned her many loyal customers. She is requesting a loan to increase her inventory of cosmetics and jewelry in order to enhance her income, thus allowing her to better contribute to the support of the family. Leticia is a member of Anointed Ladies Group, whose members provide assistance to one another in repaying the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks of cosmetics and jewelry.

loans.name: Jiguiya  (L’Espérance). Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Jiguiya est constitué de quatre femmes (trois mariées et une célibataire)vivant dans des foyers en majorité polygames dans le quartier koko de la ville de Koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles ont en moyenne 37 ans et 5 enfants. Elles mènent  comme activité principale la vente de pains,  de la  viande, des jus de fabrication locales et en plus, du bois de chauffe. Elles ont de l’expérience dans la vente de bois de chauffe et de nouriture.
Dans le souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis bientôt six ans.  Après avoir correctement remboursé tous les dix premiers prêts, le groupe Jiguiya est à son onzième prêt solidaire(prêt de groupe).
 Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour achéter du bois de chauffe dans les villages environnants de Belesso Sirakélé Tiesso et sera  revendu à la    maison. Le pain et la viande grillée ne peuvent être stockés, sont achétés et vendus quotidiennement pendant la récréation devant les écoles. Elles vendent généralement au comptant en détail et à crédit à une clientèle constituée de toutes les catégories sociales.
Ainsi avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 75 000 CFA de bénéfice chacune au cours de ce cycle. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et faire face aux charges courantes de la famille.
 Dans l’avenir, le groupe compte obtenir  un prêt élévé pour pouvoir diversifier les marchandises.
texts.en:
The Jiguiya group is made up of four women (three married and one single) who live in mostly polygamous households in the Koko neighborhood in the city of Koutiala (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are on average 37 years old with 5 kids. Their principal business is selling bread, meat, locally-produced juice, and firewood. They have experience selling firewood and food. With the idea of increasing the size of their business, the members decided to use Soro Yiriwaso’s credit program, which they have been doing for six years. After having repaid each of their ten first loans, the Jiguiya group is on its eleventh group loan. The current loan will be used to buy firewood in the surrounding villages of Belesso, Sirakélé, and Tiesso and will be resold at home. The bread and grilled meat, which can’t be stocked, are bought and sold daily during recess in front of schools. They generally sell for cash or credit to a clientele consisting of all social groups. With this new loan, they intend to earn on average 75,000 CFA francs each in profit during the loan term. This profit will be used to repay the loan and meet the needs of their families. In the future, the group intends to take a bigger loan to be able to diversify their goods.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy meat, bread, and firewood

loans.name: Ildefonsa

texts.es: Ildefonsa tiene 59 años, es divorciada, vive en su propia casa construida de adobe, con sus dos hijos Víctor de 25 y Candy de 15. Ella es una trabajadora mujer que se dedica a la venta de verduras, frutas, y otros productos para sacar adelante a su familia, viene dedicándose a esta actividad desde hace 35 años, en los cuales ha sacado mucho provecho de su trabajo y gracias a él puede ofrecerle a su familia vestimenta, educación, alimentación y velar por su salud. Ildefonsa es muy feliz en su negocio, debido a que se distrae mucho en el puesto que tiene en el mercado, compartiendo con sus vecinas y con la clientela a la cual convence fácilmente de adquirir su mercadería, su carisma y buen humor le facilitan el trabajo, pero lo que lamentablemente le resulta difícil es el traslado de su mercadería a su puesto porque requiere mucho esfuerzo físico. Este es octavo préstamo con Microfinanzas PRISMA, estando muy agradecida ya que gracias a estos créditos puede crecer en su negocio. Con la cantidad que solicita comprará mayor cantidad de mercadería en vegetales, frutas y demás para aumentar sus ventas, lograr mejores ingresos y forjarle un mejor futuro a su familia.
texts.en:
Ildefonsa is a 59-year-old divorcee who lives in her own adobe house with her two children—Victor, age 25, and Candy, age 15. She is a hard-working woman who sells fruits, vegetables, and other products for a living in order to help her family get ahead. She has been in business for 35 years, during which time she has taken greatly benefited from her job. Thanks to this business, she can provide her family with food, clothing, an education, and health. Ildefonsa is very happy with her business because she can amuse herself in her market stand, sharing with her neighbors and clientele, whom she easily persuades to purchase her produce. Her charisma and good humor facilitate her work, but sadly the most difficult aspect for her is transporting her goods to her stand because it requires a great deal of physical exertion. This is her eighth loan with Microfinanzas PRISMA. She is very grateful to the microfinance institute because thanks to those loans, her business has been able to grow. With the money that she is requesting, she will purchase a greater quantity of fruits, vegetables, and other products so that she can boost sales, generate greater profits, and forge a better future for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Claudia Maria

texts.es:
Claudia es una joven de 27 años de edad, reside en Hialeah, a mucho esfuerzos ha podido terminar su carrera en administración de empresa, 
Trabajando en un colegio público  como docente de secundaria con nueve años de experiencia en las labores, con esto se ayudaba apagar sus estudios. Su esposo es maestro de obra, tiene una niña de 6 meses. Sus metas es pode tener su propia casa ya que están viviendo en la casa de su mama, este es su tercer crédito en Afodenic que lo quiere invertir en la reparación del techo del cuarto donde habita ya que esta bien deteriorado, y desea estar en buenas condiciones para proteger y cuidar a su bebe. Sus objetivos para el futuro es poder cambiar de puesto y mejorar de nivel en lo profesional, como en su vida personal.
texts.en:
Claudia is a young 27-year-old who lives in Hialeah. Through much effort she has been able to finish her studies in business administration. She helped pay for her education by working in a public school as a secondary school teacher, in which she has nine years of experience. Her husband is a construction foreman and she has a 6 month old girl. Her goal is to have her own house as they are currently living in her mother´s house. This is her third loan with Afodenic which she wants to invest in fixing the ceiling of the room she lives in as it is quite deteriorated and she would like it to be in good condition to protect and care for her baby. Her objectives for the future are to be able to change jobs and improve her standing professionally and personally.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials to repair the ceiling of a room.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth T. is fifty-five years old. She is a wife and mother of nine children. Two have completed senior high school but the rest are currently in junior and primary schools. She lives with her family in Bawjiase, a suburb of Accra, the capital city of Ghana, in a family house. She is a local manufacturer of palm kernel oil.

Palm kernel oil is produced from palm nuts. The palm kernel is a by-product of palm oil. The palm kernel is also processed through various stages to obtain the palm kernel oil which is used to prepare many local dishes like fried fish and pastries.

Making palm oil is one of the common occupations among local women in the town of Bawjiase. Elizabeth produces it and supplies it to food vendors to prepare their meals. However, her production is on the low side as a result of low working capital to purchase palm kernel in bulk. She wants to use the loan to buy seventy bags of palm kernel and an electric cracking machine to reduce the drudgery of manual effort to help produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help her to raise more income to support her family and finance her children’s education. She is a member of community group called "Special Trust Group". In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and provide assistance to one another in handling repayment.

loans.use: to buy seventy bags of palm kernels and an electric cracking machine

loans.name: Manco Kapac Group

texts.es:
La asociación denominada “Manco Kapac” pertenece a la familia de  pro-mujer hace más de tres años. Cada catorce días se reúnen en el centro focal Alto Lima, de la ciudad de El Alto a la fecha el grupo  cuenta con trece miembros y  han demostrado ser un grupo organizado en cuanto a sus cuotas de crédito.
Dentro el grupo la mayoría son casadas y con hijos, cuentan que las ganancias de sus pequeños negocios solo cubren necesidades básicas y no les alcanza para ahorrar. Existen diferentes negocios  dentro la asociación como ser; la Gastronomía, venta de artefactos electrónicos, la venta  de fruta, venta de detergentes, además de estas otras de las socias son artesanas, realizan tejido a mano de mantas en telares, creación de muñecos tradicionales en aguayo y también tejidos en lana, confección de maletines y mochilas en cuero y aguayo, tejido de chalinas y medias en lana de alpaca y el diseño de joyas en oro y plata. La asociación Manco Kapac necesita de  capital  para comprar materia prima, con la seguridad de ampliar sus ganancias para obtener estabilidad económica en sus hogares.
texts.en:
The "Manco Kapac" association has belonged to the Pro-Mujer family for more than three years. They meet every fourteen days in the Alto Lima center in the city of El Alto. The group has thirteen members and has shown itself to be organized with regard to loan installments. The majority of the group's members are married, with children. Their small businesses cover their basic living expenses but don't stretch far enough for them to save. Among the businesses that the group's members operate are buying and selling food, electronics, fruit and detergent. Other members make and sell crafts: home-made woven blankets; traditional cloth dolls; wool cloth; bags and packs made from leather and aguayo; traditional woven scarves; socks made from alpaca wool; and gold and silver jewelry. The Manco Kapac association needs a loan to buy basic materials so that they can increase their earnings and the well-being of their households.
