Anastasia is a member of the "Sacuyo" communal bank in the town of Sacuyo, district of Acora, Puno province. She is 38 years old, has five children, is married and completed primary school. She has worked with the Manuela Ramos movement for the past 6 months and was loaned S/. 500 new soles, which was used for her grocery store so that she could increase her income and meet her group commitments. With this loan for S/. 500 new soles, which will be repaid in 3 installments, she will buy more merchandise (sacks of rice, sugar, boxes of canned tuna, milk and other goods) and in this way better stock her business so that she can have more income.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a variety of products: rice, sugar, milk, etc.

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es:
Ana María Dávila C. tiene la edad de 32 años, su estado civil es soltera, Doña Ana tiene 2 hijos su edades son las siguientes su hijo mayor de 10 años que cursa el 5 grado de primaria y su hijo menor de 8 años cursa el 3 grado de primaria, los propósitos de Doña Ana son de mantener su actividad económica por lo que para ella es muy importante, sus deseos son de garantizar a sus hijos un futuro lleno de estudios por lo que para ella como Madre le gustaría ayudar a sus hijos a que logren ser unos futuros profesionales por que hoy en día la situación esta muy difícil y esta  es una  gran oportunidad para sus hijos, sus sueños son de propiciarle mejoras a su vivienda ya que tiene ciertos desperfectos y le gustaría realizarlos.


La actividad económica es la venta de comida y refrescos, la ubicación de su negocio es en su casa de habitación situada en la siguiente dirección de la cuarta sección 2 cuadras el oeste 1 ½ al norte, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 3 años, Doña Ana inicia este negocio surge por la necesidad de obtener una fuente de ingreso para mantener a su familia ya que es ella quien se encarga de pagar las deudas de su hogar por lo que decidió incursionar en el negocio de la venta de comida por la que empezó a elaborar comidas como: gallo pinto, queso frito y arroz con pollo por lo que sus primeros clientes fueron sus vecinos ya que estos le dieron la pauta para seguir adelante y así logra obtener su fama para con su clientela, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo que será utilizado para la compra de granos básicos como arroz, frijoles, pollo, azúcar y algunos utensilios de cocina ya que todo esto es necesario para la elaboración de su comideria y además podrá ofrecer la variedad de comida a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Ana Maria D. C., 32, is single. She has two children, a 10-year old son in the fifth grade and an 8-year old son in the third grade. Ana's goal is to keep her business going, something that's extremely important to her. Her greatest wish is that her sons get a good education because she would like to see them adopt professional careers. Things are tough these days but her boys have a chance to get ahead with a good education. She would also like to improve her house because it needs repairs that she would like to make.

Ana operates a business selling food and cold drinks. Her business is located in her house and she's operated it for 3 years. She started the business because she needed a source of income to support her family and pay household debts. She decided to set up a food business and started making dishes such as: "gallo pinto" (a traditional Central American dish made with rice and beans), fried cheese, and chicken and rice, first for the neighbors who had pointed her in the right direction for getting ahead and, as her fame grew, a wider customer base. The loan will be used for working capital to buy basic supplies such as rice, beans, chicken, sugar and cooking utensils, all the things Ana needs to make her dishes.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Liliey Julia

texts.es:
La señora Julia es socia del Banco Comunal “Sacuyo”, del sector II, de la comunidad de Sacuyo, distrito de Acora, Provincia de Puno, Departamento de Puno; de  39 años de edad, tiene dos  hijos, es madre soltera y posee estudios de primaria completa.
Trabaja hace poco tiempo con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos, se dedica a comprar y vender animales menores (cuyes) y vender sus quesos, la venta lo hace en las ferias del mercado; su primer préstamo fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, ella invirtió en la alimentación de sus animales, compro platos cerámicos, gazaperas y otros.
Con este préstamo de S/ 500.00, el cual cancelará en 3 cuotas, ella invertirá en la compra de semillas  (cebada, alfalfa), alimento (afrecho, concentrado, etc.), comprará más cuyes para aumentar su producción y obtener buenas ganancias; Ella agradece a Manuela Ramos por su confianza, ya que le permitió mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Julia is a member of the "Sacuyo" communal bank, in section II of the town of Sacuyo, district of Acora, province and department of Puno. She is 39 years old, has two children, is a single mother and completed primary school. She has worked with the Manuela Ramos movement for a short time. She buys and sells small animals (guinea pigs) and sells cheese. She makes her sales at the markets. Her first loan was for S/. 500 new soles, which she invested in food for her animals, bought feed dishes, cages and other goods. With this loan for S/. 500, which will be repaid in 3 installments, she will invest in the purchase of seeds (barley, alfalfa), feed (brans and mixed grains), and will buy more guinea pigs to increase her production and make a good profit. She is grateful to Manuela Ramos for their trust, which has allowed her to improve her family´s standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy seeds and food for small animals (guinea pigs).

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.es:
La señora Aurelia es socia del Banco Comunal “Sacuyo”, sector Dos, de la comunidad de Sacuyo, distrito de Acora, Provincia de Puno, Departamento de Puno; tiene 43 años de edad, y esta al cuidado de cuatro hijos, casada y posee estudios de primaria incompleta (quinto de primaria).
Trabaja desde hace año medio con el MMR, ella se dedica al engorde y venta de ganado en las ferias ganaderas, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, que los invirtió en la compra de alimento para su ganado.
Con este préstamo de S/. 800.00 Nuevos soles, el cual pagará en 3 cuotas,  comprará alimento balanceado para su ganado, medicinas y semillas, y así podrá obtener un buen peso de su ganado y a su vez obtener buenas ganancias; ella agradece a Manuela Ramos por su confianza, ya que le permite ayudar a sus hijos en sus estudios.
texts.en:
Aurelia is a member of the "Sacuyo" communal bank in Dos, in the town of Sacuyo, district of Acora, Puno province. She is 43 years old and cares for four children, is married and her primary studies are incomplete (fifth grade). She has worked with MMR for a half year. She works at fattening up and selling livestock at the livestock markets. Her first loan was for S/. 500 new soles, which she used to buy feed for her livestock. With this loan for S/. 800 new soles, which will be repaid in 3 installments, she will buy balanced feed for her livestock, medicines and seeds so that they can reach a good weight and she can have good earnings. She is grateful to Manuela Ramos for their trust in her, which has allowed her to help her children with their education.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy feed and medicine for livestock. Buy seeds.

loans.name: Marcial

texts.es:
El Señor de Nombre Marcial B. A. tiene 47 años de edad, su estado civil es casado, Don Marcial tiene 2 hijos sus edades son las siguientes su hijo mayor de 18 años cursa el 3 año de la carrera y su hijo menor de 12 años cursa el 1 año de secundaria, su esposa labora en una ferretería, sus propósitos son de mantener su clientela ya que son el apoyo económico por medio ha sobrevivido con su familia, sus deseos son de establecer una tienda de ropa en la que encontrara una variedad de mercadería como lo es ropa para damas, caballeros y niños, ya que en esta época es muy difícil mantener un negocio de este tipo por lo cual el podría administrarlo, sus sueños son de mejorar sus condiciones de vida ya que le gustaría poder propiciarle a su esposa todas las comodidades que se merece y también a sus hijos para que estos puedan tener un futuro económico para que no pasen necesidades.

Su actividad económica es la de mercadería en general, la ubicación de su negocio es de manera ambulante, el tiempo que tiene de poseer este negocio es de 6 años, Don Marcial inicia este negocio después que lo despiden de su trabajo de la empresa Enel que en un momento formo parte del estado y mas tarde vendida a una empresa española por lo que deciden realizar recorte de personal y da inicio con otro negocio como lo es la venta de bolis o helados pero al ver la poca  ganancia que le generaba decide incorporar la venta de ropa de crédito de forma ambulante luego gracias a Dios y su experiencia como administrador logra nuevamente incorporarse a la vida profesional en una empresa donde aprovecha las oportunidades y distribuye su mercadería a los trabajadores contando también con el apoyo de su esposa que contribuye en dicha actividad teniendo como meta establecer un local fijo y sustentar los gastos diarios del hogar, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo ya que el con su esposa realizan las compras de la mercadería para distribuirla a su clientela además agradece el contar con la Fundación León 2000 y las organizaciones amigas.
texts.en:
Marcial B. A. is 47 years old. His civil status is married. Marcial has two children whose ages are the following: his eldest son is 18 years old and he's in his third year of his career studies and his younger son is 12 and he's in his first year of secondary school. His wife works in a hardware store. Their goals are to serve their customers since they provide the economic support through which they've survived with their family. Their desires are to establish a clothing store in which one will find a variety of merchandise such as clothing for women, men and children. Since, at this time, it is difficult to maintain such a business, he could manage it. Their dreams are to improve their living conditions. He would like to give his wife all the comforts she deserves, and his children so that they may have a fruitful future and not want for necessities. His job is in general merchandise. His business is of the "on foot" nature. He's had this business for six years. Marcial began this business after he was laid off from his job at the Enel company, which at one time was part of the state and later was sold to a Spanish company that decided to cut personnel. He started with another business selling icy pops and ice cream. However, upon seeing the little earnings that it generated, he decided to incorporate sales of clothing on credit on foot. Then, thanks to God, and to his experience as a manager, he was able to enter professional life again with a company where he took advantage of the opportunity to distribute his merchandise to the workers, relying also on the support of his wife who contributes to said activity having as a goal to establish a fixed shop and to support the daily expenses of the household. The loan is for working capital since he and his wife purchase merchandise for distribution to their customers. Additionally they are grateful to Fundación León 2000 and friends.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Sebastiana

texts.es:
La señora Sebastiana es socia del Banco Comunal “Sacuyo”, sector Nueva Alianza, de la comunidad de Sacuyo, distrito de Acora, Provincia de Puno, Departamento de Puno; de 36 años de edad, tiene tres hijos, es casada y posee estudios de primaria completa.
Trabaja desde hace año medio con el MMR y se presto S/. 500.00 nuevos soles ella se dedica a comprar y vender de ganado para engordar y su venta lo hace en las ferias ganaderas, ella invirtió en la alimentación de su ganado.
Con este préstamo de S/ 500.00 que pagara en 3 cuotas, lo invertirá en la compra de semillas  (cebada, alfalfa), alimento (afrecho, concentrado, etc.) para asegurar una buena alimentación del ganado y obtener con un buen peso y a su vez obtener buenas ganancias. Ella agradece a Manuela Ramos por su confianza, ya que le permitió mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Sebastiana is a member of the "Sacuyo" communal bank, in the Nueva Alianza section of the town of Sacuyo, district of Acora, province and department of Puno. She is 36 years old, has three children, is married and completed her primary school education. She has worked with MMR for a half year and was loaned S/. 500 new soles which she invested in feed for her livestock. She buys and sells livestock which she fattens up and sells in the markets. With this loan for S/. 500, which will be repaid in 3 installments, she will invest in purchasing seeds (barley, alfalfa), feed (brans, feed mix, etc.) to insure that her livestock are well-fed and reach a good weight so that she can make a good profit. She is grateful to Manuela Ramos for their trust which has allowed her to improve her family´s standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy seeds and food for livestock.

loans.name: Marcos

texts.es:
El señor Marcos J. tiene ya mas de un año con su negocio de abarrotes, es el fuente de ingresos de su familia para poder darle lo mejor ya que tiene 4 hijos y dos de ellos están estudian.
Don Marco desea que su negocio crezca más y tener variedad de productos, como es papelería, mercería, perfumería y artículos para el hogar.  Pero en este momento no cuenta con el capital necesario para poder invertir en su negocio.
Es por eso que solicita de esté préstamo para poder comprar la mercancía y así no tener que descapitalizar su negocio. Y tener más ingresos para su familia.
texts.en:
Marcos J. has had his grocery store business for more than a year. It is the source of income for his family to give them the best he can. He has 4 children, two of whom are studying. Marco would like his business to grow more and to have a variety of products like stationery, notions, perfume and articles for the home. But he does not currently have the money he needs to invest in his business. For this reason, he is requesting a loan so he can buy merchandise and not have to take capital out of his business. And to increase his family´s income.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Rogelia

texts.en:
Rogelia is engaged in planting and selling vegetables, which are mostly eggplants harvested from their own back yard. To improve her business, Rogelia would like to ask for financial support amounting to PHP10,000. She will use the loan to buy different kinds of vegetables in the public market which she will sell in their village. She only goes to the market twice or thrice a week, since they have a limited access to transportation. Part of the loan will also be used to buy a variety of vegetable seeds which she will plant in their back yard. Through her business, she can help her husband in meeting the needs of their family and somehow uplift their lives.

She is aware that she is getting old and while she has the strength, she will do her best for their family. Her husband Valeriano is a farmer and they both work as laborers when they are not busy with their own businesses for additional income. They have poor living conditions and keep struggling to live a better way. Their five children are: Rocky – 25 years old, a vocational course graduate; Conrado – 22 years old, grade four; Lorvy – 19 years old, high school graduate; Marlito – 17 years old, who never had the chance to study and Rubelyn – 9 years old, currently in grade two.

They live in a mountainous village of Cabisera in Isabela province. Despite poverty, they manage to have a good relationship in the family and are all hoping to have a progressive life.

loans.use: Purchase more vegetables and vegetable seeds

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan is engaged in the hog raising business, which has been her way of helping her husband Ruben, a farmer, in earning income for the daily needs of their family. The couple has two children: Robejane – 5 years old and Jenny Rose – 2 years old. They have poor living conditions in the village and they both cultivate rice and corn as their main source of income.

She is now asking financial assistance amounting to PHP 4,000 that she will use to purchase feeds for her hogs. She is hoping that in the coming months she will be able to add at least one or two hogs for her business to grow. Joan said that through the lenders who provide her with financial support and with her hard work and faith in God, nothing is impossible in achieving her dreams. Her investment in the business will also be of great help in sending her children to school in the coming year.

loans.use: Purchase feeds for her hogs

loans.name: Rose Ann

texts.en:
Rose Ann maintains her rice vending business to help her husband earn a living for their family.  She wants to make her business grow so she is requesting a loan of PHP 6,000.  The said amount will be utilized to buy a sack of rice that she will sell at retail price.  Aside from selling rice, Rose Ann is engaged in raising 45-day-old chicks that she also sells afterward.  One of her hopes is for her family to have their own house in the village.  
	 
Rose Ann is 26 years old and her husband Rolando is working as a rice and corn classifier.  They have a one-year-old daughter and they are currently living in her parents’ house and her husband is visiting them on weekends since he is working in a distant place.  She is thankful that she has a responsible and loving husband.

loans.use: purchase a sack of rice

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.en:
For ten years, Felicitas has been working as a beautician. Her beauty skills became her great capital in helping her husband earn enough for their daily necessities. At present, she is in need of financial assistance and she would like to borrow PHP 7,000 which she will use to purchase beauty accessories that she needs to cope with new fashions. She also has skill in cutting hair for men and women. She also wants to engage in peanut butter making or maybe in the business of buying and selling goods to increase her daily income and to save for the education of her three children. Felicitas is hoping to achieve all her business plans for the future of her children.

Felecitas is 37 years old. She is married to Jovito, a carpenter. Their children are: Jevoi, 3 years old; Benvick Jovani, 6 years old, a pre-school student and Jonila, 13 years old, a second year high school student.

loans.use: purchase beauty accessories

loans.name: Marcela

texts.en:
Marcela and her husband Felino Servillo are engaged in vegetable planting and vending. Aside from that, she also ventured into the hog-raising business. The couple was blessed with six children: Jilmer – 24 years old, high school graduate; Ana – 18 years old, also a high school graduate; Aisa – 13 years old, grade six student; Angelica – 11 years old, grade four; Nimfa – 6 years old, a pre-school student and Shaina, three years old. The family is living in the mountainous place of Hacienda San Antonio in Ilagan, Isabela with an average standard of living.

At present, Marcela is asking for financial support that she can use in her farming and hog-raising business. She is hoping that through the loan amount of PHP 5,000 their businesses will grow. This will also encourage them to persevere for the improvement of their livelihood and to have a better life in the future. This financial assistance will also be helpful in sending their children to school. She believes that “life is like a wheel, sometimes you’re on top and sometimes at the bottom”. She believes that someday they will reach the top as long as they join hands and work harder.

loans.use: to be used in her farming and hog-raising business

loans.name: Salehe

texts.en: Salehe J. is a Tanzanian micro-entrepreneur. He runs a phone accessories shop at Tabata ward in Dar es Salaam. The phone accessories are purchased from the big phone shops in Kariakoo city market. His future plan is to run a wholesale shop but capital is a limiting factor. He needs a loan of Tshs 800,000 to buy more phone accessories.

loans.use: To buy more business inventory

loans.name: Raya

texts.en: Raya S. is a Tanzanian micro-entrepreneur, a married woman with four children. She runs a charcoal store at Mbagala ward in Dar es Salaam. The demand for charcoal for domestic use as a main source of power is very high in most developing countries due to high electricity costs and unreliability.  Raya purchases charcoal bags wholesale directly from the charcoal producers. She has been in the business for six years. She needs a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.use: To purchase more business inventory

loans.name: Sultan

texts.en: Sultan M. is a Tanzanian, an entrepreneur, and a married man with two children. He runs a kiosk business at Kigamboni Island in Dar es Salaam. He sells varieties of items including fruits. Business items are purchased from Kariakoo and Buguruni city market center. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 800,000. to purchase more business items.

loans.use: to expand the business by purchasing more stocks

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace A. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur who runs a Kindergarten school with fifty school kids and also sells clothes at Kisiwani Ward in Dar es Salaam. She has been running the business for the last four years. She purchases the clothes from Kariakoo and Karume city market centers and sells them to retails customers. Her husband has passed away leaving her with a single kid who is in standard four. She plans to expand her school by building more classes. She is requesting a loan of Tshs 800,000. to boost up the business.

loans.use: To buy more school items

loans.name: Sugran Abdul Majeed Group

texts.en:
"My name is Sugran and I am a 52-year-old married lady. I have been a citizen of a city called Borewala, Pakistan for the past 25 years. I am an uneducated lady and I don’t hesitate to mention it. My parents were not in a position to bear my education expenses. My husband's name is A. M. and he is a delivery man and delivers goods, e.g. fruits & vegetables and construction supplies, on his donkey cart. He has been doing this work for the past 15 years. I am the mother of four kids: two sons and two daughters. My elder son runs a tea stall in the community. People come to him for taking tea. They admire his tea. My elder daughter has a carpet weaving business. I help my daughter sell her handmade carpets. The others don't have jobs and stay at home and do household work. I have successfully repaid my first loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now I am applying again for a loan to buy materials (cloth, colored thread, and sketches) to expand my daughter’s carpet weaving business.

I am the group leader for some more women from my locality. Ameena baji wants a loan to buy wood for her furniture-making business. Parveen Akhtar baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business. Kalsoom baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for transport. Waziran baji wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for weaving carpets

loans.name: Bilquis Akhtar M.aslam Group

texts.en:
Bilquis Akhtar baji is a 39-year-old lady and has resided in a city called Borewala, Pakistan for the past 25 years. She got divorced from her husband 4 years ago due to some personal problems and then she moved to her parents' house with two daughters. She started working with her brother who is involved in a flour-selling business. Now they both doing this work and sell the flour in different cities (Lahore, Multan). With the profit, she got her daughters registered in school so that they are able to continue their studies and make their future bright. She has successfully repaid her first loan which she took from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy more flour to expand the flour-selling business.

Bilquis Akhtar baji is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Nargis baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for transport. Sharifan baji wants a loan to buy wood for her furniture-making business. Fatima baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Nazia baji wants a loan to buy wood to re-sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy flour to sell

loans.name: Shahnaz William Masih Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz baji is a 28-year-old married lady and resides in a city named Borewala, Pakistan. Her parents were not in a position to bear her education expenses; that’s why she left her education after 5th standard. She is the mother of three kids: one son and two daughters. Her elder daughter is 5 years old and reads in kindergarten. Her son and her youngest daughter are not of a school-going age.

Shahnaz baji’s husband's name is W. M. and he deals with wood. He buys wood and sells it in the community, since gas is not available. She helps her husband to tie the wood in bundles and to sell in the community. She successfully repaid her two previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to expand her husband’s wood selling business.

She is the group leader of some more women of her locality. Bushra baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Tahira parveen baji wants a loan to buy bicycles to resell. Shahnaz begum baji wants a loan to buy clothes to resell. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk selling business. Rahal baji wants a loan to buy wood to resell. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy material (cloth, thread and sketches) for her carpet weaving business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy wood to sell

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna P., 48, is a vegetable farmer and a vendor at the same time. She is accompanied by her husband named Gaudencio in her business activity by simply maintaining their rice and vegetable crops such as eggplant, pepper, and “ampalaya” (bitter gourd). Aside from that, the couple also maintains their hog-raising business to further improve their living conditions. Her two children stopped studying when they were young due to financial constraints.

Edna wants to receive a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 to be able to purchase a complete fertilizer which is needed in their vegetable and rice business to generate higher income. Edna sells her vegetable produce wholesale to buyers who come to their village and retails also them when she has sufficient time to roam around their village. Edna and her husband consider each other and their family as inspiration for success.

loans.use: purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Bashiran Majeed Masih Group

texts.en:
Bashiran baji is a 46-year-old married lady and has resided in a city named Borewala, Pakistan, for the past 25 years. Her husband's name is M. M. and he has an animal food selling business. He has been in this business for the past 15 years.

She is the mother of three kids: two sons and one daughter. Her sons are also involved in their father’s business. Her daughter is 12 years old and stays at home and does household work. Bashiran baji is involved in a milk selling business. She has a buffalo at her house and gets milk from her by getting up early in the morning. She does this work to share the financial burden of her husband. She successfully repaid her two previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy animal food to resell.

She is a group leader of some more women of her locality. Fozia baji and Razia baji each want a loan to buy leather to resell. Wanaliat baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk selling business. Farzana baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats) to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animal food to sell

loans.name: Kosar M. Manzoor Group

texts.en:
Kosar baji is a 39-year-old married lady and has resided in a city called Borewala, Pakistan for the past 20 years. She completed her education up to 5th standard and couldn’t study further due to the meager income of her father. She is married to a man whose name is M. M. and he is a mason by profession. She is the mother of four kids: two sons and two daughters. Her elder son is employed in a motor workshop. The others have no jobs. Her husband only gets income when he gets a contract to construct a building. Now he is planning to start a shuttering business to earn good income. Kosar baji helps him by doing embroidery on dresses. She collects orders from her neighbors and charges them $3 per dress. She is applying for a loan to buy beams and rope to start a shuttering business.

She is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Taj baji wants a loan to buy tires for her tractor. Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Shama baji wants a loan to buy wood for her furniture-making business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for shuttering business

loans.name: Caridad

texts.en:
Caridad D. is a mother of three who is helping her husband-farmer in earning a living through her rice vending business which serves as their alternative source of income. She is also able to help her husband's farming needs through this other source of income.

She is currently requesting a loan of Php 4,000 to be used as additional capital in her rice vending business. She also stressed that she must work hard in order to have unique business strategies to grow her business and ultimately have a higher income for her family. She also hopes to give her children the best education so that they can get decent jobs someday.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Rubina Iqbal Masih Group

texts.en:
Rubina baji is a 44-year-old married lady and has resided in a city called Borewala, Pakistan for the past 16 years. She completed her education up to 10th standard and then got married to a man whose name is I. M. and he has been involved in a scrap business for the past 10 years. Rubina baji is the mother of four kids: two sons and two daughters. All of her kids are getting an education from a school near their house.

Rubina baji is a very hard-working lady. She sews clothes to take her husband out from under the financial burden and for moral support also. Her family is very happy with her attitude. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy more scrap to expand her husband’s scrap business.

Rubina baji is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics for her beauty parlor. Mukhtaran baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes-selling business. Kishwar Shaheen baji wants a loan to buy medicines for her medical store.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy scrap for scrap business

loans.name: Ceferina

texts.en:
Ceferina R., 60 years old, is married to Rogelio R., a farmer. The couple resides in a small flood-prone village of Yeban Sur.  They have five children Jovelyn – 37, a teacher; Nestor, 36, a soldier; Janette, 33, a teacher, Gregorio, 29, an agriculture graduate and Mark Gil, 19, who is currently third year College. She is happy seeing all her children achieving a better future through better education. However, Ceferina is concerned of her husband, who is currently sick, and she needs to have extra income for his medications.
 
Ceferina is requesting a loan amounting to PHP5,000 which she will use to re-open her village store business. Their current source of income is their passenger tricycle which earns for them an average monthly income of PHP3,000. The loan that she will avail will be used to buy goods for sale -- such as bottled and canned goods, detergent soaps, coffee, sugar, milk -- to open her village store.

loans.use: to be used in re-opening her village store

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
“Work hard to achieve the best”, is a quotation lived by Josephine Q..  She is engaged in hog-raising business, an enterprise that she wants to grow through hard work, so that she can support the needs of their family especially for the education of their children.

She is 45 years old, married to Romeo, a farmer, who also guides her in the hog-raising business.  They have seven children: Jayson, 20,  and Jocelyn,18, both elementary undergraduates; Mylene,15, elementary graduate; Jessica,13, second year high school student; Jemalyn, 9, in elementary grade two; Racelle,5, a pre-school student and Regie, 3 years old. 

Josephine is requesting a loan of around PHP6,000 that she will use to expand her business by purchasing additional hogs and feeds.  She hopes and will strive hard to improve her business to meet the growing needs of their family, particularly that the prices of commodities are increasing.

loans.use: for business expansion, purchase hogs and feeds

loans.name: Shamim Rahmat Masih Group

texts.en:
Shamim baji is a 56-year-old married lady and has resided in a city called Borewala, Pakistan for the past 40 years. She couldn’t get an education because her parents couldn’t afford her education expenses. Her husband's name is R. M. and he is a wood seller by profession. He has been selling wood for the past 25 years.

Shamim baji also helps him in his wood-selling work. They divide the work hours between themselves. Shamim baji sells wood in the shop in the morning and her husband sells wood in the evening. Shamim baji is the mother of two sons. Her elder son runs a salon and the other has a mobile phone shop. Shamim baji successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more wood to expand her wood-selling business.

She is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Farzana baji and Shabana baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shop. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy wood to re-sell. Fozia baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit for her fruit-selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy wood to re-sell

loans.name: Irshad Amanat Masih Group

texts.en:
I. baji is a 30 year old married woman and has lived in a city named Borewala, Pakistan for the past 12 years. Her husband's name is A. M. who has two businesses: fruits and vegetables and groceries. He has been doing this work for the past 10 years. I. baji is a mother of five children: three sons and two daughters. Her eldest son is a mason. The others are enrolled in school and getting an education. I. baji helps her husband in his grocery shop. When her husband goes to sell fruits and vegetables she handles the grocery shop by herself. Her husband is very happy with her support. She has successfully paid back two previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a new loan to buy groceries to expand her grocery shop. 

She is the leader of a group of women. Zubaida baji and Shamim baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy bicycles for her bicycle selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own individual business. The members mutually guarantee their loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible for the missing repayment.

loans.use: To buy groceries and bicycles

loans.name: Rukhsana Bashir Masih Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana baji is the wife of B. M. and resides in a city called Borewala, Pakistan for the past 26 years. Her husband runs a grocery shop in the community. People come to him to buy groceries for their houses. He has a good reputation from his behaved with the customers.

Rukhsana baji is the mother of one daughter who is just 1 year old. Rukhsana baji stays at home and sews clothes for her neighbors. She does this work to help her husband to renovate the house. She feels proud to share some effort with her husband. She has completed two loans from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy groceries to expand her grocery shop.

She is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Irshad baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics for her beauty parlor. Zubaida baji wants a loan to buy a movie camera for her movie-making business. Naziran baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for their grocery shop

loans.name: Parveen Rahmat Masih Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji is a 43-year-old married lady and has resided in a city called Borewala, Pakistan for the past 25 years. Her husband's name is R. M. and he is a driver by profession. Parveen baji is the mother of two kids: one son and one daughter. Her son works in a factory for a monthly wage. Her daughter is 12 years old and stays at home and does household work.

Parveen baji is involved in a sewing business. She takes orders for clothes from her neighbors. Her daughter helps her in sewing clothes. She invests her income in a committee and plans to marry off her daughter when she becomes 18. She has successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a micro-finance institute inPakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) for her husband so that he will be able to earn a good income.

She is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Shakra baji and Shazia baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops. Nasreen baji and Bashiran baji and Khalida baji each want a loan to buy wood to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Khalida Habib Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Khalida baji is a 37-year-old married lady and has resided in a city named Borewala, Pakistan, for the past 22 years. She is married to a man whose name is H. A. and he runs a grocery shop in the community. People come to him to buy groceries for their houses. He has been running his grocery shop for the past 15 years.

Khalida baji is a mother of one son whose name is A. Raza and he is 3 years old. Khalida baji is an expert in the making of Punjabi food. She sells a Punjabi dish named “Daal chawal” in the community. She does this work to share the financial burden of her husband and also to admit her son into a good school. She successfully repaid her two previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy groceries to expand her husband’s grocery shop.

She is the group leader of some more women of her locality. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy a rubbing machine which is used to smooth floors. Another Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy scissors and razors for her salon. Khalida baji and Sugran baji each want a loan to buy donkey carts for their loading businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Parveen Akhtar M. Ramzan Group

texts.en:
My name is Parveen Akhtar and I’m 30 years old. I am married and my husband, M. R., sells construction supplies. He has been doing this work for 10 years. I have passed the 12th standard (grade) in school and I run an academy where I teach students. I am also a mother of four children: three sons and one daughter. All of my children are getting their education from a school near our house. I’m applying for a loan to buy more construction supplies (cement and sand) to expand my husband’s business. 

I’m a group leader of a group of women in my neighborhood. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy wood to resell. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Ghulam Fatima baji wants a loan to buy scissors and razors for her hair salon. Abida Kanwal baji wants a loan to buy medicine for her medical store. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To biuy construction supplies

loans.name: Jannat Abdul Nishar Group

texts.en:
Jannat baji is a 24-year-old married woman who has lived in Borewala, Pakistan all of her life. She couldn't get an education because her parents couldn’t pay for her educational expenses. Her husband, A. N., has been selling wood for the past 2 years. 

Jannat baji is the mother of two children: one son and one daughter. Her son is 4 years old and her daughter is just 1 year old. Jannat baji stays at home and share her husband’s financial burden by embroidering dresses. She collects orders from the neighbors and charges $3 for each embroidered dress. She is applying for a loan to buy more wood to expand her husband’s wood business. 

She is the leader of a group of women in her neighborhood. Jamila baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Shagufta Parveen baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothing business. Another woman, also named Jamila baji wants a loan to buy wood to resell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: "Baji," which means "older sister," is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy wood to resell

loans.name: Sakina Shoqat Ali Group

texts.en:
My name is Sakina and I’m 33 years old. I have been a citizen of Borewala, Pakistan for the past 12 years. I couldn’t get my education because my parents could not pay for the educational expenses. 

I am married to S. A., who sells Punjabi food. He sells samosas (a pastry filled with potatoes, onions, and peas) and pakodas (a fried snack made from onions, chili, and coriander) and people used to come to him to buy these items. He has a good reputation among people. I help my husband to prepare these items. My husband is very happy with me. I am applying for a loan to buy cooking oil, spices and flour to expand my husband’s Punjabi food business. 

I’m the leader of a group of women in my locality. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Parveen baji wants a loan to buy masonry tools. Shamim Kosar baji wants a loan to buy cloth, thread and sketches for her carpet-weaving business. Anwar baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Tahira Parveen baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: 'Baji,' which means 'older sister,' is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for a food business

loans.name: Anwar Ghulam Fareed Group

texts.en:
Anwar baji is a 38-year-old married woman and has lived in Borewala, Pakistan for the past 20 years. Her husband, G. F., drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). He has 15 years of driving experience.

Anwar baji is a mother of nine children: six daughters and three sons. Her first three daughters are involved in a carpet-weaving business. Her eldest son is a cobbler. The others are free and don’t do anything. Anwar baji helps her daughters in their carpet-weaving business. They weave carpets based on orders that they collect from the carpet sellers. Anwar baji charges 4,000 Pakistani rupees (~ $50 USD) per carpet. 

Anwar baji successfully repaid her two previous loans from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. Now she is applying again for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) for her husband so that he is able to get the full reward for his work. 

She is a the group leader of a group of women of her locality. Sugran baji wants a loan to buy mobile phones for her mobile phone shop. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy fertilizer to resell. Zahida baji wants a loan to repair her tractor. Another woman, also named Sugran baji, wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: "Baji," which means "older sister," is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Nabeela Royan Masih Group

texts.en:
Nabeela baji is a 35-year-old married woman who has lived in Ismail Nagar in Lahore, Pakistan for the past 20 years. Her parents were not able to provide a good education for her, so she left her school after completing 5th standard. She is married to R. M.. He has been selling children's clothing for the past 4 years. 

Nabeela baji is the mother of seven children: three sons and four daughters. Her eldest son does lath work. The others attend a school near their house. Nabeela baji belongs to a family of farmers. She has a buffalo in her house and takes care of it. She gets milk from her and sells the milk in milk shops and earns a profit. She does this work to fulfill the needs of her children. 

Nabeela baji successfully repaid her two previous loans from Asasah, a microfinance institute of Pakistan. Now she is applying again for a loan to buy more garments to expand her husband’s business. 

She is the group leader of a group of women of her locality. Munawar baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her cloth  business. Ghafooran baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Mussarat baji wants a loan to buy tools for her business repairing electric items. Razia baji wants a loan to buy wood to resell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: "Baji," which means "older sister," is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy garments to sell

loans.name: Shamim Tariza Amanuel Group

texts.en:
Shamim tariza baji is a 44-year-old married lady and has resided in an area named Ismail Nagar of city Lahore, Pakistan, for the past 27 years. Her husband's name is A. and he works in a factory. Shamim baji has three kids: two sons and one daughter. Her elder son works in a factory. The others are free and don’t do anything.

Shamim baji sells clothes to share the financial burden with her husband so that they both easily manage the household's expenses. She buys clothes from a famous city (Multan) and sells in her native city Borewala. She has been in this work for the past 15 years. She successfully repaid her two previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to expand her clothes selling business.

She is the group leader of some more women of her locality. Agnus baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Kosar parveen baji wants a loan to buy material (leather, polish and nails) for her shoe making business. Chanda baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Bushra baji wants a loan to buy masonry tools to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Shama James Group

texts.en:
Shama baji is a 28-year-old married lady and has lived in an area called Ismail Nagar of the city of Lahore, Pakistan for the past 11 years. She completed her education up to 5th standard but couldn’t study further because her parents were not able to provide for her education. She is married to a man whose name is J. and he is a driver by profession. He drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) with an experience of 6 years. She is the mother of five children: four daughters and one son. All of her kids are getting an education from a local school.

Shama baji is a very responsible lady. She gives priority to her family over herself. She gets up early and does all the household work. After that she sews clothes to share the financial burden of her husband. She has successfully repaid her three loans from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to pay the remaining installments of her husband’s auto-rickshaw.

Shama baji is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Mumtaz baji wants a loan to buy material (cloth, beads, and colored thread) for her decorative embroidery business. Maria baji wants a loan to buy mobile phones for her mobile phone shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To pay the remaining installments of her husband's auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Mwanahawa

texts.en: Mwanahawa M. runs a kiosk at Mbagala Ward in Dar es Salaam. She is married with two children, one is in kindergarten and the other one is in primary school. She sells soft drinks and other domestic items. She intends to open a big shop but unfortunately she doesn't have enough funds.She requests a loan of Tshs 800,000. to boost up the business

loans.use: To purchase more business stock

loans.name: Ayesha Zulfiqar Ali Group

texts.en:
"My name is Ayesha and I’m 26 years old and a married lady, a citizen of an area of Lahore called Ismail Nagar for the past 7 years. My husband's name is Z. A. and he is a vegetable seller by profession and has been selling vegetables for the past 10 years. I’m the mother of two children: one son and one daughter. Both of my kids are in kindergarten. I and my husband have a dream to see our kids in a very good position. To achieve this, I prepare decorative embroidered dresses on order. I charge $3 per dress. I have successfully repaid my three loans from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now I am applying again for a loan to buy more seasonal vegetables to expand my husband’s vegetable selling business. "I am the group leader for some more women from my locality. Sajida baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business. Rashidan baji wants a loan to buy wood to re-sell. Naseem K. baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics to sell. Rashidan baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop."

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal vegetables to sell

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en: Tatu A. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and a married woman. She runs a café at Mbagala ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases some of her business items from Kariakoo city market, and others from Mbagala market in Dar es Salaam. Her customers mostly come from Mbagala market. She is requesting a loan of Tshs 600,000 to meet her customers' demand.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Irshad Bhola Masih Group

texts.en:
Irshad baji is a 42-year-old married lady and has been a citizen of an area of the city of Lahore called Ismail Nagar, Pakistan for 20 years. She is an uneducated lady but lives with a dream to give her children a better future. Her husband's name is B. M. and he is a driver by profession, driving an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

Irshad baji is the mother of three kids: two sons and one daughter. Her elder son is a driver; he also drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). The others enrolled in a school and getting an education. Irshad baji is a sweeper. She works in a government office for a monthly wage. She invests her income in a committee and plans to marry off her daughter when she gets the whole amount. She is applying for a loan to pay off the installments of her son’s auto-rickshaw.

Irshad baji is the group leader for more women from her locality. Azra baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Bushra baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics to sell. Mumtaz baji wants a loan to pay off the installments of her family's auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To pay off the remaining installments of an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en: Mohamed J. is a Tanzanian entrepreneurial businessman. His business is selling coconuts in Kariakoo Dar es Salaam. He purchases coconuts direct from producers and sells to retailers for domestic use. He has been in this business for six years. Coconuts are used by many people as a spice and sometimes for cooking oil production in industries. They are mainly produced in the coastal region. He needs a loan to buy more product.

loans.use: To purchase more stock.

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en: Hadija H. S. runs a shop at Mbagala Ward in Dar es Salaam Tanzania. She is married with four children. She sells different types of grain products including wheat flour, maize flour, beans, cashew nuts, ground nuts, sugar, etc. She purchases the products from wholesale shops and from Kariakoo City market. Her business income is used to meet the children's school fees and the daily needs of the family. She requests a loan to buy more stock

loans.use: To buy more stock

loans.name: Phares

texts.en: Phares N. is a Tanzanian entrepreneurial man. He runs a business of a cosmetics shop at Ukonga ward in Dar es Salaam. He purchases the items from Kariakoo city market wholesale shops and other wholesale shops in Buguruni marketing center. Phares is planning to run a wholesale cosmetics shop at Kariakoo business city center but lacks the necessary funds. Therefore, he is requesting a loan to buy more stock and produce more income.

loans.use: To buy more stock.

loans.name: Khursheed Begum Group

texts.en:
Khursheed begum baji is a 48 year old married lady who has lived in Pakpattan, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Pakpattan city is famous for its shrine places, which people visit to make wishes. Her husband's name is N. A. who is a daily wage laborer. She is the mother of one son who works in a factory. Khursheed baji has a fruit selling business, which she runs from home. People of her community come to her to buy fruit. She does this work to share the financial burden of her family, because inflation is increasing day by day. She is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruits to earn a good income.

She is a group leader of some more women of her locality. Naseem baji wants a loan to buy goats for her animal selling business. Nasreen begum baji wants a loan to buy another video game for her game shop. Nooran baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Sharifan baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits for her fruit selling business.

loans.name: Anwar Mukhtar Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Anwar baji is a 33 year old married lady, who has lived in Pakpattan, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Pakpattan city is famous for its shrine places, which are visited by people who want to make wishes. She married a man whose name is M. A., and he runs a food business in the community. He sells Punjabi food specifically, and people come to him to buy their food. He has been running this business for the past 25 years. Anwar baji is a mother of four kids: three daughters and one son. All of her children are receiving their education from a school which is located near their house. Anwar baji herself is involved in a business of sewing clothes. She sews clothes to share the financial burden of her husband, so that he can manage the household expenses easily. She is applying for a loan to buy products (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for their food selling business. 

She is a group leader of some more women of her locale. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy wheels for different vehicles to sell. Naseem baji wants a loan to buy wheat to sell. Zainab baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits to resell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy products for food business.

loans.name: Irshad Akbar Ali Group

texts.en:
Irshad baji is a 49 year old married lady who has lived in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Pakpattan city is famous for its shrine places. People come to this city to visit the shrine places where they make wishes. Her husband's name is A. A., who is a milk seller by profession. He has been doing this work for the past 12 years. Irshad baji helps her husband get milk from the buffalo. Presently, they have one buffalo at their house.

Irshad baji has two sons. Her elder son works in a factory and the other one runs a grocery shop. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy another buffalo to expand their milk selling business.

She is a group leader of some more women in her neighbourhood. Shamshad baji wants a loan to buy material (thread, elastic and cloth) for her ribbon making business. Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk selling business. Ghafooran baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for her sewing business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for milk selling business.

loans.name: Shazia M. Hassan Group

texts.en:
Shazia baji is a 33 year old married lady who has lived in Pakpattan, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Pakpattan city is famous for its shrine places, and people visit the shrine places to make wishes. She completed her education up to 5th standard but couldn’t study further because of her family’s lack of financial resources. She married a man whose name is M. H., and he is a driver by profession. He drives a 32 seat local bus and charges fares to people. Shazia baji has three kids: two daughters and one son. All of her children are receiving their education from a school located near their house. Shazia baji has a dream of giving her children a good education, because in her childhood she was fond of education but couldn’t get it. She prepares embroidered dresses to pay the school fees for her kids. She is applying for a loan to repair her husband’s vehicle named “Coaster”. 

She is a group leader of some more women of her locale. Nazia baji wants a loan to buy biscuits to sell. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Maryam baji wants a loan to buy rice to sell. Zahida parveen baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair a vehicle named "Coaster"

loans.name: Naseem Akhtar M. Din Group

texts.en:
Naseem akhtar baji is a 53 year old married lady who has lived in Pakpattan, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Pakpattan city is famous for its shrine places. People come to this city to visit the shrine places to make wishes. Her husband's name is M. D., who has been a ticket checker for the Railway for the past 30 years. Naseem baji is a mother of four kids: three sons and one daughter. All of her kids are getting their education from a school located near to their house. Naseem baji and her husband have a dream to see their children do well, and for that dream they work hard. She sews clothes by taking orders from her neighbors, both day and night. She is a highly determined lady who wants to achieve her dream. She is applying for a loan to buy another sewing machine because her old machine is starting to have problems. 

She is a group leader of some more women of her locale. Abida parveen baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes. Jannat baji and Sumera baji each want a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Saima baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.  

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another sewing machine for sewing clothes.

loans.name: Naseem M. Ramzan Group

texts.en:
Naseem baji is a 33 year old married lady who has resided in a city named Arifwala in Pakistan, for the past 15 years. She is an uneducated lady. She is married to M. R., who is a cobbler by profession. He makes shoes for men and children, and he learned this art from his father. Naseem baji is the mother of two sons, who both help their father in his shoemaking business. Naseem baji also helps her husband make the shoes. This business has become their family business. She is applying for a loan to buy material (leather, nails and polish) to complete the orders of customers.

She is a group leader of some more women of her locale. Jannat baji wants a loan to buy remote controls for televisions to resell. Naheed baji wants a loan to buy material (biscuits and chips) for her canteen. Aroosa baji wants a loan to buy material (colored thread and tools) for her carpet weaving business. Shamim akhtar baji wants a loan to buy material (cloth, colored thread and sketches) for her embroidery business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy materials for shoemaking business.

loans.name: Ghulam Fatima M. Idress Group

texts.en:
Ghulam Fatima baji is a 40 year old married lady, and a citizen of a city named Arifwala, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Her husband's name is M. I. who has a utensils selling business, which he has done for the past 20 years. Ghulam Fatima baji helps her husband by selling utensils in the community. They both are very happy with each other. She is applying for a loan to buy more utensils to expand her husband’s business. 

She is a group leader of some more women of her locale. Hafizan baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Safia baji wants a loan to buy material (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy utensils to sell.

loans.name: Manuel Antonio

texts.es: Don Manuel tiene 33 años de edad, habita en memorial sandino, junto con su esposa que le tiene dos hijos de 5 y 7 años de edad, uno de los niños va a clase a primer grado en el colegio del barrio, su negocio es la venta de leña y presta el servicio de acarreo en un carretón de caballos, que ha sido su subsistencia ya que la gente ocupa muchos de sus servicios por los bajos costos, su esposa tiene una pequeña pulpería que día a día va creciendo y esperan salir cada día en mejores condiciones, el inicio este negocio por que su papa trabajaba ganándose la vida en este trabajo, y aprendió mucho,es un trabajo cansado, y que la mayor parte anda uno sucio pero es rentable y desea superarse para poder ayudar a su familia, con este préstamo que afodenic, le esta brindando es para hacer las paredes de su casa y poder gozar de una vivienda digna, para esto va  comprar materiales de construcción, como piedra, arena, cemento, hierro entre otros. Sus planes es comprar otro caballo para seguir dando mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Manuel is 33 and lives in the Memorial Sandino neighborhood with his wife and two children, 5 and 7, one of whom is in first grade at the local school. Manuel sells firewood and provides transportation services using his horse and wagon. He spends a lot of time serving his clients for a very low cost, so he just gets by. His wife has a small general store that is growing by the day. They hope to make daily improvements to their quality of life. Manuel chose his business because he learned a lot from his father, who earned his living the same way. His work is tiring and fairly dirty, but it is profitable and he wants to better himself so he can help his family. Manuel is seeking a loan from AFODENIC to build walls for his house so he can enjoy a decent home. He'll need to buy construction materials, such as stone, sand, cement, iron, etc. His plans include buying another horse so he can continue providing better service to his clients.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials to build walls for his house

loans.name: Celia Pastora

texts.es: Doña Celia  tiene 35 años de edad, habita en un barrio de la capital de Managua que se llama memorial sandino, junto a su esposo y sus hijos, son dos de 14 y 18 años de edad,  que están cursando sus estudios, su esposo trabaja de cadete de taxis trabajo agotador y a veces están mal y tiene que buscar clientes en toda la ciudad para ayudar a su familia. La Sra. Celia tiene una pulpería, la cual inicio con ayuda y recursos que su esposo dio, para cubrir las necesidades del desempleo de el. Este es su segundo crédito con este va invertir en la compra de productos variados para surtir la pulpería y se incrementen las ventas, que espera que sea de mucho beneficio como en su negocio, como en su vida personal para salir adelante y poder seguir apoyando a sus hijas con los estudios. Sus planes a  futuro es poder tener un mayor financiamiento para poder crecer y tener otra diversidad de productos, también espera seguir mejorando su casa.
texts.en:
Celia is 35 years old and lives in the Memorial Sandino neighborhood of the capital city, Managua. She lives with her husband and two children, who are 14 and 18 years old. Her children are students and her husband works as a taxi driver, which is exhausting work. Sometimes things don’t go well and he has to drive all over the city looking for customers so he can earn money to take home to his family. Celia has a general store which she opened with money that her husband gave her so she could support them when he was unemployed. This is the second loan that she has requested and she will use the loan to invest in the purchase of various products to stock her store and increase sales. She hopes that this will help the store a great deal, as well as help her get ahead in her personal life and keep supporting her children’s education. In the future she plans on having better financing so the store can grow and have a greater variety of products. She also hopes to keep improving her home.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products to stock her general store

loans.name: Glenda Esther

texts.es: La Sra. Glenda tiene 46 años de edad,  reside en el barrio Jonathan González, en la ciudad de Managua, con dos hijos que trabajan  por su propia cuenta ya que con esfuerzos tienen ganado, se dedican al negocio de ganadería. Doña Glenda vende electrodomésticos, ropa, cosméticos, desde hace ocho años, en las ventas que comenzó con ahorros propios solo vendiendo ropa, con esta solicitud de préstamo quiere invertir en la compra de ropa variada, y de colegio ya que es la temporada que se vende mas por que inicia un nuevo curso del año, su objetivo es aumentar el volumen de venta que le genere mayores ganancias, a corto plazo es seguir haciendo mejoras a su casa y terminarla.
texts.en:
Glenda is 46 years old and lives in the Jonathan González neighborhood in the city of Managua. She has two children who already have bought livestock and work as ranchers. Glenda has sold domestic electronics, clothing, and makeup for 8 years. She began her business with her own savings and just sold clothing. She would like to use this loan to invest in the purchase of a variety of clothing, particularly school uniforms because it is the time of year when school begins and she sells many school uniforms. Her goal is to increase her sales so she can earn more income. She hopes to soon be able to continue improving her house and complete it.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing for children and adults

loans.name: Cesar Antonio

texts.es: El Sr. Cesar a la edad de 49 años ha podido sobresalir  adelante desde muy joven a trabajado de ayudante de ebanista, reside en Memorial Sandino, su esposa es ama de casa y con dos hijos de 12 y 16 años de edad, los cuales cursan la secundaria, el inicio con ahorro propios  y con conocimientos que adquirió alo largo de los años  ahora tiene su propio taller, y se siente gozosos por lograr sus objetivos , también ha alcanzado estos logros gracias a los préstamo que ha hecho con Afodenic esta es la quinta solicitud y va invertir en comprar  madera para elaborar variedad de mueble y ofertar al mercado, con esto espera buenos ingresos para seguir desarrollándose en las ventas. Sus planes a largo plazo es poder apoyar a sus hijos con los estudios para que sean hombres íntegros a esta sociedad, a si como buscar nuevas rutas de ventas.
texts.en:
Cesar is 49 years old and has been able to stand out since he was young. He worked as an assistant to a cabinetmaker, and now lives in the Memorial Sandino neighborhood. His wife is a homemaker and his two children are 12 and 16 years old, both in high school. He began his business with personal savings and now with the knowledge he has acquired over the years he has his own workshop and feels happy that he has achieved his goals. He has also achieved other things thanks to loans from Kiva partner Afodenic. This is the fifth loan that he has requested and he will use the it to buy wood to make a variety of furniture, which he will sell in the market. He hopes to make a good income from the sales which will let him make more sales in the future. His long-term plans are to be able to help his children with their studies so they will become important men in society, and to find new avenues for sales.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wood to make furniture

loans.name: Maria Del Rosario

texts.es: La Sra. Maria del Rosario tiene 39 años de edad y reside en la colonia Sagastume de la ciudad capiptal, ella se dedica a la venta de tortillas en su casa de habitacion, tiene su negocio hace varios años, las tortillas que produce las vende en una fabrica avicola y las que le sobran las vende de forma ambulante cerca de su colonia, con los ingresos que percibe con sus ventas ha logrado poder levantar su casa de habitacion y tambien este negocio le brinda a sus hijos alimentacion y estudio, ella solicita un credito para poder salir adelante y mejorar la calidad de vida de sus hijos
texts.en:
Maria del Rosario is 39 years old and resides in Sagastume, a suburb in the capital city. She is dedicated to selling tortillas in her home. She's had her business for various years. She sells the tortillas that she produces in a poultry factory and she sells whatever is leftover on foot near her area. With the income that she makes from her sales she has been able to improve her residence. Also this business provides food and education to her children. She is requesting a loan so she can get ahead and improve her children's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase corn, corn flour, firewood, etc.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Francisco Jose

texts.es: Don Francisco Rodríguez un hombre que se ha esforzado en la vida para sobresalir con sus estudio a muchas dificultades,  se recibió en Licenciatura en ciencia de la computación, tiene 48 años de edad, reside en el barrio Francisco Salazar de la distribuidora  tres cuadras al este, felizmente su esposa procreo tres hijos de 12,16,17 años de edad, que están cursando los estudios para lograr tener un nivel de vida mejor, su esposa es ama de casa, el señor Francisco  se desempeña en una empresa de responsable de almacén, desde hace veinte y ocho años, en donde ha podido desarrollarse profesionalmente en su trabajo como individuo. Con las solicitudes que ha hecho en afodenic, ha logrado hacer mejoras a su casa, esta es la segunda solicitud la cual va invertir en  seguir mejorando su vivienda, para esto va a comprar materiales de construcción como: piedra, arena, zinc, perlinez y otros. Para hacer las mejoras de su casa y  gozar de los beneficios de su trabajo como dicha institución que le apoya con los préstamos de  bajos costos de interés.
texts.en:
Mr. Francisco Rodríguez is a man who has worked very hard in his life to succeed in his studies, with many difficulties. He is 48 years old and has a degree in computer science. He lives in the Francisco Salazar neighborhood, three blocks to the east of the distributor. He and his wife have three children together, ages 12, 16 and 17, and they are all studying in order to achieve a better standard of living. His wife is a housewife, and Francisco has worked as a grocery store manager for 28 years, where he has been able to develop both professionally and personally. With the loan that he received from Kiva partner Afodenic, he made improvements to his home. This is his second loan, which he will use to keep improving his home. He will buy construction materials such as: stone, sand, zinc, beams and others. He looks forward to making the improvements to his house and enjoying the benefits of his work with Afodenic, which has supported him with low-interest loans.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials to repair the walls and roof of his home

loans.name: Leocadio Casildo

texts.es: el Sr. Leocadio y su esposa Mary Cruz se dedican a la elaboracion y venta de golosinas como ser baleadas, tajaditas de platano, tortillas con quesillo, chilaquiles y otros, tambien los fines de semana vende nacatamales y sopas, su negocio esta ubicado en la colonia Altos de Santa Rosa, el negocio es muy limpio y cuenta con mesas y sillas para darle una mejor atencion a sus clientes que a diario lo visitan para comer en su local, los clientes los prefieren a ellos porque son bien amables y tienen una atencion especial para sus clientes. ellos en estos momentos desean hacer crecer su negocio y estan solicitando un credito para poder hacerlo.
texts.en:
Leocadio and his wife Mary Cruz make and sell sweets, as well as baleadas (a Honduran tortilla filled with mashed, fried beans and possibly other ingredients), fried plantains, tortillas with cream cheese filling, chilaquiles (a fried corn tortilla dish with green or red salsa and other ingredients), amongst others. On weekends, they also sell Honduran tamales (called nacatamales) and soup. Their business is located in the Altos de Santa Rosa neighborhood. It is very clean and has tables and chairs in order to better serve the customers that return on a daily basis to eat on the premises.
